however, recent classifications suggest that the Mallophaga are [[Paraphyly|paraphyletic]] and four suborders are now recognized:{{cite web |url=http://phthiraptera.info/ |title=Phthiraptera.info |author=Smith, Vince |publisher=International Society of Phthirapterists |accessdate=25 October 2015}} * [[Anoplura]]: [[sucking]] lice, occurring on mammals exclusively * [[Haematomyzus|Rhynchophthirina]]: parasites of elephants and [[warthog]]s * [[Ischnocera]]: mostly avian chewing lice, however, one family parasitizes mammals * [[Amblycera]]: a primitive suborder of chewing lice, widespread on birds, however, also live on South-American and Australian mammals Nearly 5,000 species of louse have been identified, about 4,000 being parasitic on birds and 800 on mammals. Lice are present on every continent in all the habitats that their host animals and birds occupy. They are found even in the [[Antarctic]], where [[penguin]]s carry 15 species of lice (in the genera ''[[Austrogonoides]]'' and ''[[Nesiotinus]]'').{{cite journal |last1=Banks |first1=Jonathan C. |last2=Paterson|first2=Adrian M. |title=A penguin-chewing louse (Insecta : Phthiraptera) phylogeny derived from morphology |journal=Invertebrate Systematics |date=2004 |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=89–100 |doi=10.1071/IS03022 |url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/IS03022.htm}} File:Ricinus bombycillae (Denny, 1842).JPG|''Ricinus bombycillae'', an Amblyceran louse from the [[bohemian waxwing]] File:Trinoton anserinum (Fabricius, 1805).JPG|''Trinoton anserinum'', an Amblyceran louse from a [[mute swan]] File:Lice image01.jpg|''Damalinia limbata'' is an Ischnoceran louse from [[goat]]s. The species is [[sexual dimorphism|sexually dimorphic]], with the male smaller than the female. ===Phylogeny=== Lice have been the subject of significant [[DNA]] research in the 2000s that led to discoveries on human evolution. The three species of sucking lice that parasitize human beings belong to two genera, ''Pediculus'' and ''Pthirus'': head lice (''Pediculus humanus capitis''), body lice (''Pediculus humanus corporis''), and pubic lice (''Pthirus pubis''). Human head and body lice (genus ''Pediculus'') share a common ancestor with chimpanzee lice, while pubic lice (genus ''Pthirus'') share a common ancestor with gorilla lice. Using phylogenetic and cophylogenetic analysis, Reed et al. hypothesized that ''Pediculus'' and ''Pthirus'' are sister taxa and monophyletic. In other words, the two genera descended from the same common ancestor. The age of divergence between ''Pediculus'' and its common ancestor is estimated to be 6-7 million years ago, which matches the age predicted by [[Chimpanzee–human last common ancestor|chimpanzee-hominid divergence]]. Because parasites rely on their hosts, host-parasite cospeciation events are likely. Genetic evidence suggests that our human ancestors acquired pubic lice from [[gorilla]]s approximately 3-4 million years ago.{{cite journal |title=Pair of lice lost or parasites regained: the evolutionary history of anthropoid primate lice |author1=Reed D.L. |author2=Light, J.E. |author3=Allen, J.M. |author4=Kirchman, J.J. |journal=[[BMC Biology]] |volume=5 |issue=7 |doi=10.1186/1741-7007-5-7 |year=2007 |url=http://www.biomedcentral.com/1741-7007/5/7 |pmid=17343749 |pmc=1828715}} Unlike the genus ''Pediculus'', the divergence in ''Pthirus'' does not match the age of host divergence that likely occurred 7 million years ago. Reed et al. propose a ''Pthirus'' species host-switch around 3-4 million years ago. While it is difficult to determine if a parasite-host switch occurred in evolutionary history, this explanation is the most parsimonious (containing the fewest evolutionary changes). Additionally, the DNA differences between head lice and body lice provide corroborating evidence that humans used clothing between 80,000 and 170,000 years ago, before leaving Africa.{{cite web |last1=Parry |first1=Wynne |title=Lice Reveal Clues to Human Evolution |url=http://www.livescience.com/41028-lice-reveal-clues-to-human-evolution.html |publisher=LiveScience |accessdate=25 October 2015 |date=7 November 2013}} Human head and body lice occupy distinct ecological zones: head lice live and feed on the scalp, while body lice live on clothing and feed on the body. Because body lice require clothing to survive, the divergence of head and body lice from their common ancestor provides an estimate of the date of introduction of clothing in human evolutionary history.{{cite journal |author1=Kittler, R. |author2=Kayser, M. |author3=Stoneking, M. |year=2003 |title=Molecular Evolution of ''Pediculus humanus'' and the Origin of Clothing |journal=Current Biology |volume=13 |issue=16 |pages=1414–1417 |doi=10.1016/S0960-9822(03)00507-4 |pmid=12932325}} The mitochondrial genome of the human species of body lice (''[[Pediculus humanus|Pediculus humanus humanus]]''), the head louse (''[[Pediculus humanus|Pediculus humanus capitis]]'') and the pubic louse (''[[Pthirus pubis]]'') fragmented into a number of minichromosomes, at least seven million years ago.{{cite journal |author1=Shao, R. |author2=Zhu, X.Q. |author3=Barker, S.C. |author4=Herd, K. |year=2012 |title=Evolution of extensively fragmented mitochondrial genomes in the lice of humans |journal=Genome Biology and Evolution |volume=4 |issue=11 |pages=1088–1101 |doi=10.1093/gbe/evs088 }} Analysis of mitochondrial DNA in human body and hair lice reveals that greater genetic diversity existed in African than in non-African lice.{{cite journal |author1=Light, J.E. |author2=Allen, J.M. |author3=Long, L.M. |author4=Carter, T.E. |author5=Barrow, L. |author6=Suren, G. |author7=Raoult, D. |author8=Reed, D.L |year=2008 |title=Geographic distribution and origins of human head lice (''Pediculus humanus capitis'') based on mitochondrial data |journal=Journal of Parasitology |volume=94 |issue=6 |pages=1275–1281 |doi=10.1645/GE-1618.1 }} Human lice can also shed light on human migratory patterns in pre-history. The dominating theory of [[Anthropology|anthropologists]] regarding human migration is the [[Recent African origin of modern humans|Out of Africa Hypothesis]]. Genetic diversity accumulates over time, and mutations occur at a relatively constant rate. Because there is more genetic diversity in African lice, the lice and their human hosts must have existed in Africa before anywhere else. The phylogeny of the Phthiraptera is shown, not yet fully resolved, in the [[cladogram]]:([http://www.insecta.bio.spbu.ru/z/pdf/Kluge2004-189-229-elibrary.pdf Kluge 2005], [http://www.mapress.com/bionomina/content/2010/f/bn00001p055.pdf Kluge 2010], [http://www.insecta.bio.spbu.ru/z/pdf/Kluge2012-Neoptera.pdf Kluge 2012]): {{clade|style=font-size:85%;line-height:85% |label1=Neoptera |1={{clade |1=[[Embioptera|webspinners]], [[Dictyoptera|cockroaches]], [[Phasmatodea|stick insects]] and allies |label2=[[Eumetabola]] |2={{clade |label1=[[Parametabola]] |1={{clade |label1=[[Zoraptera]] |1=(angel insects) |label2=[[Paraneoptera]] |2={{clade |label1=[[Thysanoptera]] |1=(thrips) |label2=[[Hemiptera]] |2=(bugs) |label3=[[Psocodea]] |3={{clade |label1=[[Trogiomorpha]] |1=(scaly-winged barklice) |label2=[[Troctomorpha]] |2={{clade |1=Amphientometae |2=Nanopsocetae |3='''Phthiraptera''' (lice) }} |label3=[[Psocomorpha]] |3=(booklice, barklice) }} }} }} |label2=[[Metabola]] |2=[[beetle]]s, [[Hymenoptera|wasps]], [[Diptera|flies]], [[Lepidoptera|butterflies]], and allies }} }} }} ==In human culture== ===In social history=== [[File:Louse diagram, Micrographia, Robert Hooke, 1667.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|left|Drawing of a louse clinging to a human hair. [[Robert Hooke]], ''[[Micrographia]]'', 1667]] Lice have been intimately associated with human society throughout history. In the [[Middle Ages]], they were essentially ubiquitous. At the death of [[Thomas Becket]], [[Archbishop of Canterbury]] in 1270, it was recorded that "The vermin boiled over like water in a simmering cauldron, and the onlookers burst into alternate weeping and laughing".{{cite journal |last1=Kowalski |first1=Todd J. |last2=Agger |first2=William A. |title=Art Supports New Plague Science |journal=Clin. Infect. Dis. |date=2009 |volume=48 |issue=1 |pages=137–138 |doi=10.1086/595557 |url=http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/48/1/137.full |pmid=19067623}} A mediaeval treatment for lice was an [[ointment]] made from pork grease, [[incense]], [[lead]], and [[aloe]].{{cite book |last=Elliott |first=Lynne |title=Clothing in the Middle Ages |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qtq_WSpdo0gC&pg=PT29 |year=2004 |publisher=Crabtree |isbn=978-0-7787-1351-7 |page=29}} [[Robert Hooke]]'s 1667 book, ''[[Micrographia|Micrographia: or some physiological descriptions of minute bodies made by magnifying glasses with observations and Inquiries thereupon]]'', illustrated a human louse, drawn as seen down an early [[microscope]].{{cite web |last1=Hooke |first1=Robert |title=Microscopic view of a louse |url=http://prints.royalsociety.org/art/580831/microscopic-view-of-a-louse |publisher=The Royal Society |accessdate=17 October 2015}} [[Margaret Cavendish]]'s satirical ''[[The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World]]'' (1668) has "Lice-men" as "mathematicians", investigating nature by trying to weigh the air like the real scientist [[Robert Boyle]].{{cite book |last=Sarasohn |first=Lisa T. |title=The Natural Philosophy of Margaret Cavendish: Reason and Fancy During the Scientific Revolution |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sE0XnNgF9ZoC&pg=PA167 |year=2010 |publisher=JHU Press |isbn=978-0-8018-9443-5|pages=165–167 |quote=The Bear-men were to be her Experimental Philosophers, the Bird-men her Astronomers, the Fly- Worm- and Fish-men her Natural Philosophers, the Ape-men her Chymists, the Satyrs her Galenick Physicians, the Fox-men her Politicians, the Spider- and Lice-men her Mathematicians, the Jackdaw- Magpie- and Parrot-men her Orators and Logicians, the Gyants her Architects, &c.}}{{cite book|last1=Cavendish|first1=Margaret|title=The Description of a New World, Called the Blazing-World|date=1668|publisher=A. Maxwell|url=http://digital.library.upenn.edu/women/newcastle/blazing/blazing.html}} In 1935 the Harvard medical researcher [[Hans Zinsser]] wrote the book ''Rats, Lice and History'', alleging that both body and head lice transmit typhus between humans.{{cite book |last1=Zinsser |first1=Hans |title=Rats, Lice and History |date=2007 |origyear=1935 |publisher=Transaction Publishers |isbn=978-1-4128-0672-5}} Despite this, the modern view is that only the body louse can transmit the disease.{{cite web |last1=Altschuler |first1=Deborah Z.|title=Zinsser, Lice and History |url=http://www.headlice.org/faq/disease/zinsser.htm |publisher=HeadLice.org |accessdate=19 October 2015 |date=1990}} [[File:Jan Siberechts "Cour de ferme" détail Scène d'épouillage.jpg|thumb|upright|Detail showing delousing from [[Jan Siberechts]]' painting ''Cour de ferme'' ("Farmyard"), 1662]] Soldiers in the trenches of the [[First World War]] suffered severely from lice, and the [[typhus]] they carried. The Germans boasted that they had lice under effective control, but themselves suffered badly from lice in the [[Second World War]] on the Eastern Front, especially in the [[Battle of Stalingrad]]. "[[Delousing]]" became a grim [[euphemism]] for the extermination of Jews in [[concentration camp]]s such as [[Auschwitz]] under the Nazi regime.{{cite web |last1=Evans |first1=Richard J. |authorlink1=Richard J. Evans |title=The Great Unwashed |url=http://www.gresham.ac.uk/lectures-and-events/the-great-unwashed |publisher=Gresham College |accessdate=17 October 2015}} In the psychiatric disorder [[delusional parasitosis]], patients express a persistent irrational fear of animals such as lice and mites, imagining that they are continually infested and complaining of itching, with "an unshakable false belief that live organisms are present in the skin".{{cite web |last1=Weinstein |first1=Phillip |title=Entomophobia/Delusionary Parasitosis; Illusionary Parasitosis |url=http://medent.usyd.edu.au/fact/delpara.htm |publisher=University of Sydney Department of Medical Entomology |accessdate=17 October 2015}} ===In science=== The human body louse ''Pediculus humanus humanus'' has (2010) the smallest insect [[genome]] known.{{cite journal |author=Kirkness, Ewen F.; et al. |year=2010 |title=Genome sequences of the human body louse and its primary endosymbiont provide insights into the permanent parasitic lifestyle |journal= Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America |volume=107 |issue=27 |pages=12168–12173 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1003379107 |pmid=20566863 |pmc=2901460}} This louse can transmit certain diseases while the human head louse (''P. h. capitis''), to which it is closely related, cannot. With their simple life history and small genomes, the pair make ideal [[model organism]]s to study the [[Molecular biology|molecular mechanisms]] behind the transmission of [[pathogen]]s and [[Vector (epidemiology)|vector]] [[Natural competence|competence]].{{cite journal |author1=Pittendrigh, Barry R. |author2=Berenbaum, May R. |author3=Seufferheld, Manfredo J. |author4=Margam, Venu M. |author5=Strycharz, Joseph P. |author6=Yoon, Kyong S. |author7=Sun, Weilin |author8=Reenan, Robert |author9=Lee, Si Hyeock |author10=Clark, John M. |year=2011 |title=Simplify, simplify: Lifestyle and compact genome of the body louse provide a unique functional genomics opportunity |journal=Communicative and Integrative Biology |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=188–191 |doi=10.4161/cib.4.2.14279 }} ===In literature and folklore=== [[File:Mother_Louse,witch_Wellcome_L0000658.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Mother Louse, a notorious [[Alewife (trade)|Alewife]] in Oxford during the mid 18th century. Her crest includes 3 lice. Image by [[David Loggan]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l68ZhT2agbEC&pg=PA275|title=Notes & Queries|last=|first=|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1859|isbn=|location=|pages=275–276|author=William White}}{{Cite paper|publisher=University of York|last=Pierce|first=Helen|title=Unseemly pictures: political graphic satire in England, c. 1600-c. 1650|date=2004|url=http://etheses.whiterose.ac.uk/9864/1/423697_vol1.pdf}}]] [[James Joyce]]'s 1939 book ''[[Finnegans Wake]]'' has the character Shem the Penman infested with "[[foxtrot]]ting fleas, the lieabed lice, ... bats in his belfry".{{cite book |last1=Joyce |first1=James |title=Finnegans Wake |date=1939 |publisher=Faber |page=180}} Clifford E. Trafzer's ''A [[Chemehuevi]] Song: The Resilience of a [[Southern Paiute]] Tribe'' retells the story of Sinawavi ([[Coyote]])'s love for Poowavi (Louse). Her eggs are sealed in a basket woven by her mother, who gives it to Coyote, instructing him not to open it before he reaches home. Hearing voices coming from it, however, Coyote opens the basket and the people, the world's first human beings, pour out of it in all directions.{{cite book |last=Trafzer |first=Clifford E. |title=A Chemehuevi Song: The Resilience of a Southern Paiute Tribe |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GA81CgAAQBAJ&pg=PA24 |date=2015 |publisher=University of Washington Press |isbn=978-0-295-80582-5 |pages=22–25}} The Irish songwriter John Lyons (b. 1934) wrote the popular song ''The Kilkenny Louse House''. The song contains the lines "Well we went up the stairs and we put out the light, Sure in less than five minutes, I had to show fight. For the fleas and the bugs they collected to march, And over me stomach they formed a great arch". It has been recorded by Christie Purcell (1952), Mary Delaney on ''From Puck to Appleby'' (2003), and the [[Dubliners]] on ''[[Double Dubliners]]'' (1972) among others.{{cite web |last1=Carroll |first1=Jim |title=Songs of Clare: The Kilkenny Louse House |url=http://www.clarelibrary.ie/eolas/coclare/songs/cmc/the_kilkenny_louse_house_jlyons.htm |publisher=Clare Library |accessdate=19 October 2015}}{{cite web |last1=Scott |first1=Bruce |title=My Colleen by the Shore |url=http://www.veteran.co.uk/VT149CD%20Paginated%20booklet%20pages.pdf |publisher=Veteran |year=2013 |accessdate=25 October 2015}} [[Robert Burns]] dedicated a poem to the Louse, inspired by witnessing one on a lady's bonnet in church: "Ye ugly, creepin, blastid wonner, Detested, shunn'd, by saint and sinner, How dare ye set your fit upon her, sae fine lady! Gae somewhere else, and seek your dinner on some poor body." [[John Milton]] in ''[[Paradise Lost]]'' mentioned the biblical plague of lice visited upon pharaoh: "Frogs, lice, and flies must all his palace fill with loathed intrusion, and filled all the land." [[John Ray]] recorded a Scottish proverb, "Gie a beggar a bed and he'll repay you with a Louse." In [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Troilus and Cressida]]'', [[Thersites]] compares [[Menelaus]], brother of [[Agamemnon]], to a louse: "Ask me not what I would be, if I were not Thersites; for I care not to be the louse of a lazar, so I were not Menelaus."{{Cite book |title=Insect Life in the Poetry and Drama of England: With Special Reference to Poetry |last=Twinn |first=Cecil Raymond |publisher=University of Ottawa (PhD Thesis) |year=1942 |url=http://hdl.handle.net/10393/21088}} ==See also== *[[Pest (organism)]] *[[Use of DNA in forensic entomology]] ==References== {{Reflist|28em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Phthiraptera}} {{Wikispecies|Phthiraptera}} {{Wiktionary|louse}} *[http://npic.orst.edu/pest/lice.html National Pesticide Information Center – Understanding and Controlling Lice] *[http://entomology.ifas.ufl.edu/creatures/urban/human_lice.htm body and head lice] on the [[University of Florida]]/[[Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences]] Featured Creatures Web site *[http://entomology.ifas.ufl.edu/creatures/urban/crab_louse.htm crab louse] on the [[University of Florida]]/[[Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences]] Featured Creatures Web site *[http://www.metapathogen.com/lice/phumanus/ ''Pediculus humanus capitis'' head louse facts, myths, life cycle at MetaPathogen] * [https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Parasitic_Insects,_Mites_and_Ticks:_Genera_of_Medical_and_Veterinary_Importance/Sucking_lice Parasitic Insects, Mites and Ticks: Genera of Medical and Veterinary Importance] Wikibooks {{Human lice}} {{Psocodea|2}} {{Insects in culture}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q6481228}} [[Category:Lice| ]] [[Category:Insects in culture]]

{{Cleanup rewrite|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox video game |title = Metal Slug 5 |image = Metal Slug 5 (insert).jpg |image_size = 225px |caption = Cover art |developer = [[Noise Factory]] / [[SNK Playmore]] |publisher = [[SNK Playmore]] |designer = |series = ''[[Metal Slug (series)|Metal Slug]]'' |composer = Toshikazu Tanaka |released = November {{vgy|2003}} |genre = [[Run and gun (video game)|Run and gun]] |modes = [[Single-player]], 2 player [[Cooperative gameplay|co-op]] |cabinet = Upright |arcade system = [[Neo Geo (console)|Neo-Geo]] (708 Mbit [[cartridge (electronics)|cartridge]]) |display = [[Raster graphics|Raster]], 304 x 224 pixels (Horizontal), 4096 colors |platforms = [[Arcade game|Arcade]]
[[Neo Geo (console)|Neo Geo]]
[[PlayStation 2]]
[[Xbox (console)|Xbox]]
[[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] }} {{nihongo|'''''Metal Slug 5'''''|メタルスラッグ 5}} is a [[Run and gun (video game)|run and gun]] [[video game]] for the [[Neo Geo (console)|Neo-Geo]] console/arcade platform created by [[SNK Playmore]]. It was released in 2003 for the MVS arcade platform, is the fifth game in the [[Metal Slug (series)|Metal Slug series]], and was one of the last games for the Neo Geo system. The game was developed by [[Noise Factory]]/[[SNK Playmore]], after Korean company [[Mega Enterprise]] had directed ''[[Metal Slug 4]]''. The biggest difference from previous titles is the addition of the slide move, which allows the player to evade and maneuver in a new fashion. Unlike its predecessor ''[[Metal Slug 4]]'', which reused many of the backgrounds from the previous games, ''Metal Slug 5'' incorporates a wealth of new environments and backgrounds and features a more [[heavy metal music|Heavy metal]] influenced soundtrack. It was later ported to [[Xbox (console)|Microsoft Xbox]] in Japan and North America only (not compatible with [[Xbox 360]]) and [[PlayStation 2|Sony PlayStation 2]] as a stand-alone game in Japan and Europe, and along with ''Metal Slug 4'' as a [[compilation (games)|compilation]] in North America and South Korea. It was also ported to [[Microsoft Windows]] for a Korean release. ==Plot== One year after the event of [[Metal Slug 7]]. A special disc that contains deep and intricate secrets about the Metal Slug project is stolen by a mysterious group called the Ptolemaic Army, whose speciality lies from within archaeological excavation and espionage. Marco and Tarma of the Peregrine Falcon Strike Force follow in hot pursuit against the group and in the process are joined by Eri and Fio of SPARROWS. Together once more, the quartet investigate the shrouded objective of the Ptolemaic Army, who over time grows more powerful as they are joined by a mysterious masked man and his followers. At the end of the game, the Ptolemaic Army summons a giant demon as the final boss, which after a long battle is forced to leave Earth thanks to the heroes. ==Differences from previous games== *The player may now perform a slide-dash. *"[[Obese|Fat]] mode" is the only remaining modifier, there are no zombies, mummies, aliens or other supernatural creatures, although the final boss is a large demon. *Morden's infantry, Morden himself and Allen O'Neil are nowhere to be found in this game; rather, one fights armies of veiled terrorists, special forces, and assorted mecha. As a result, this game lacks much of the sense of humor of its predecessors. However, most of the new enemies are mostly edits of Rebel soldier sprites. *With the exception of the first and third levels, the game does not have branching paths. *The "Flame shot" has been omitted. According to the Debug level, the Flame Shot is present in the code. *The medal system from Metal Slug 4 has been abandoned. *Playable characters Trevor and Nadia have been omitted in favor of Eri and Tarma. *There are cutscenes at various points throughout the game, rather than one or two at the end, giving the game a hint of progression of plot. *A remixed version of "Final Attack" is played whilst facing the final boss. *Depending on whether the Arcade machine has the "Blood" option turned on or off, not only the blood color will change from red to white, but the Ptolemaic Army's guerilla's T-shirt and bandanas will change from red to navy. ==New vehicles and Slugs== Only three new vehicles were added, though the Metal Slug, Slug Mariner, and Slug Flyer make a return. *The first new vehicle, the Slug Gunner, is the ultimate evolution of the Metal Slug and rebel Armor. The Gunner fires a machine gun, a chassis-mounted cannon, and can punch enemies with a close-combat exploding metal spike "cannon". The Gunner can perform a mid-air jump like that of the Level Armor. The Gunner can transform from a walker into a tank, and can move slightly faster in addition to running over [[infantry]]. However, the gunner is slow, takes a while to turn, and only has a 180-degree firing arc (360-degree while in the air). *The second new vehicle is the Car Slug or the TIAF 660. This is a car with a 360-degree vulcan cannon attached. Its secondary fire is an oversized Enemy Chaser. Of particular interest is that the player cannot eject from the vehicle, meaning they die when its destroyed, and will subsequently respawn in a new Car Slug. *The Spider Slug is a giant squid-like walker with two legs tethered to the floor and to the ceiling; jumping raises or lowers the cockpit. The Spider Slug is armed with 360-degree firing vulcan cannons, and a [[harpoon]] gun. ==Reception== {{Empty section|date=December 2014}} {{Video game reviews |MC = 71 http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox/metal-slug-4-5http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-2/metal-slug-4-5 |GR = 70.89%/70.47%http://www.gamerankings.com/xbox/920516-metal-slug-4-and-5/index.htmlhttp://www.gamerankings.com/ps2/920446-metal-slug-4-and-5/index.html }} ''Metal Slug 5'' received mixed to positive reviews from critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-2/metal-slug-4-5 |title=Metal Slug 4 & 5 for PlayStation 2 Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=2013-11-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/metal-slug-4-and-5-review/1900-6124487/ |title=Metal Slug 4 & 5 Review |publisher=GameSpot |date= |accessdate=2013-11-05}}{{cite web|last=Martin |first=Matt |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/r_metalslug5_ps2 |title=Metal Slug 5 Review • Reviews • PlayStation 2 • |publisher=Eurogamer.net |date=2006-03-13 |accessdate=2013-11-05}} It received very positive scores from players, with an average of 8.1 on GameSpot for the PS2 version and 8.4 for the Arcade version. While Metacritic and Gamrankings given with 70.47% and 70 alongside with Metal Slug 4 as compilation for both PS2 and Xbox score. ==Legacy== In 2014, a fan-made remake of the game called ''Metal Slug 5 Elite'' was released on [[Gamejolt]] for [[Microsoft Windows]], created with the [[GameMaker: Studio|Game Maker Studio]]. Retaining the story and theme of the original game, the game has tweaked some gameplay features: *The slide move reaches further than the original. *Most of the layouts of the stages are altered and changed. *The enemy AI are adjusted to fit the revamped difficulty of the game, in addition of tweaking most enemy attacks. *Problems with the Slug Gunner are now fixed, allowing it to move and turn around faster than usual. It also has the longest health than the other Slugs. *Three new weapons are introduced: the ''Flame Machine Gun'' (which has more damage than Heavy Machine Gun, and capable of burning enemy soldiers when hit), the ''Grenade Launcher'' (which fires grenade rounds that provides a large blast radius and more damage than Super Grenade), and ''Super Shotgun'' (which has more damage than the Shotgun). *The game has new cutscenes that provides more information of the original plot, as well as incorporating an original soundtrack. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://game.snkplaymore.co.jp/official/ms5/ms5_top.html ''Metal Slug 5''] at [[SNK Playmore]] *{{KLOV game|id=12904}} *Metal Slug 5 at [http://neo-geo.com Neo-Geo.com] (review) [http://www.neo-geo.com/reviews/neo-reviews/ms5/metalslug5-1.html 1] *[http://www.mobygames.com/game/metal-slug-5 Metal Slug 5 at MobyGames] {{Metal Slug series}} [[Category:2003 video games]] [[Category:Arcade games]] [[Category:Cooperative video games]] [[Category:Metal Slug]] [[Category:Neo Geo games]] [[Category:PlayStation 2 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Network games]] [[Category:SNK Playmore games]] [[Category:Terrorism in fiction]] [[Category:Video games featuring female protagonists]] [[Category:Xbox games]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games set in South Africa]] [[Category:Video games set in Texas]] [[Category:Video games set in the United States]] [[Category:Video games set in Spain]] [[Category:Video games set in Sicily]] [[Category:Video games set in Italy]] [[Category:Video games set in Tokyo]] [[Category:Video games set in Japan]]

revision.comment: Removing link(s): [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Hispanic Business]] closed as delete ([[WP:XFDC|XFDcloser]])
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox Magazine | title = Mi Gente Hispana Magazine | image_file = July_08_issue_of_Mi_Gente_Hispana.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = July 2008 cover (Issue 3, Number 14). | company = LGO Corporation | paid_circulation = | unpaid_circulation = | total_circulation = 82,211 (USA){{cite web |url=http://www.accessabc.com/index.html |title= eCirc for Consumer Magazines |date= June 30, 2011 |publisher= [[Audit Bureau of Circulations (North America)|Audit Bureau of Circulations]]|accessdate=November 30, 2011}} | circulation_year = 2010 | frequency = Monthly | language = English | category = [[Lifestyle magazine]] | editor = Michael Person
Victor Alarcon | editor_title = Editor-in-Chief | founded = 2006 | country = [[United States]] | based = [[Washington, D.C.]] | website = {{URL|http://www.migentehispana.com}} }} '''Mi Gente Hispana, Inc.''' is a media company based in [[Washington, D.C.]], in the [[United States of America]]. Founded in 2006, Mi Gente Hispana, Inc. publishes information for and about Hispanic empowerment in the United States. Mi Gente Hispana features the best thinkers, trendsetters, and next-generation leaders in the Hispanic American community. Mi Gente Hispana ignites conversation, promotes empowerment and celebrates aspiration. In a 2006 article in ''Hispanic Business'' magazine, ''Mi Gente Hispana Magazine'' is quoted as "La voz y alma de la cultura hispana." Mi Gente Hispana runs the gamut with issues that reflects highly upon Hispanic men, women, teens, children, and family. It also serves as a medium to not only inform but also entertain its audience through the use of positive images and messages. ==Target markets== The magazine is mainly marketed towards Hispanic professionals, entrepreneurs, opinion leaders, members of Hispanic organizations, and students. Mi Gente Hispana also promotes local artists by providing them a venue to showcase their talent (dance, music, fashion) via the website as well as Mi Gente Hispana's annual MGH Fest,[http://www.migentehispana.com/ Mi Gente Hispana website] which is held in numerous cities every August. ==Magazine== The company's flagship [[publication]] is ''Mi Gente Hispana Magazine''. '''''Mi Gente Hispana'' magazine''' (MGH) is the premier [[English language]] lifestyle publication for U.S [[Hispanics]]. MGH, which has been published since the spring of 2006, is the source for news and information about Hispanic culture from across the [[United States]] and around the globe. MGH knows the current events, health information, political trends and lifestyle news that the young and older [[Latin American]] audience needs and wants to know and it is delivered in a creative and stylish way. MGH forums, message boards, and [[blogs]] help readers interact with the community and keep connected to our culture. An events calendar details local events and activities for young Latino professionals happening in their local area. MGH magazine is the "bookmarked" destination for everyday users. On March 2, 2010, Mi Gente Hispana announced that it would fold the magazine as of April 1, 2010, although it would keep the web site.[http://www.migentehispana.com/ Mi Gente Hispana Magazine now available online] ==Website== Website is offline as of 4 September 2017 MiGenteHispana.Com is a comprehensive website for bringing Hispanic Culture from the streets of the Latin American community to the internet through the means of relevant topics as well as blogs. Topics including Current Events, Culture, Health and Entertainment make Mi Gente Hispana reading material for all age groups. Forums and message boards keep readers interactive with their community and their culture. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.migentehispana.com ''Mi Gente Hispana'' official website] [[Category:Spanish-language magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 2006]] [[Category:American lifestyle magazines]] [[Category:American monthly magazines]] [[Category:Cultural magazines]] [[Category:American online magazines]] [[Category:Magazines published in Washington, D.C.]]

revision.comment: ([[c:GR|GR]]) [[c:COM:Duplicate|Duplicate]]: [[File:Anefo 910-9352 Amsterdamse.jpg]] → [[File:Amsterdamse Vondelschool naar de wekelijkse museumles in het Stedelijk Museum, Bestanddeelnr 910-9352.jpg]] Exact or scaled-down duplicate: [[c::File:Amsterdamse Vondelschool naar de wekelijkse museumles in het Stedelijk Museum, Bestanddeelnr 910-9352.jpg]]
revision.text:
[[File:Amsterdamse Vondelschool naar de wekelijkse museumles in het Stedelijk Museum, Bestanddeelnr 910-9352.jpg|thumb|Children during a museum lesson at the [[Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam]] in 1960]] '''Museum education''' is a specialized field devoted to developing and strengthening the education role of non-formal education spaces and institutions such as museums. Its main objective is to engage visitors in learning experiences to enhance their curiosity and interest on their objects and collections. [[File:Dallas Museum of Art 06.jpg|thumb|Educational exhibition on "Materials & Meanings" at the [[Dallas Museum of Art]].]] In a seminal report called ''Excellence and Equity''{{cite book|title=Excellence and Equity|year=1992|publisher=American Association of Museums|isbn=978-0-931201-14-1|url=http://iweb.aam-us.org/Purchase/ProductDetail.aspx?Product_code=I277}} published in 1992 by the American Association of Museums (now the [http://aam-us.org/about-us American Alliance of Museums]), the educational role of museums was identified as the core to museums' service to the public. According to the report, "...the public dimensions of museums leads them to perform the public service of education—a term that in its broadest sense includes exploration, study, observation, critical thinking, contemplation and dialogue". As museum education has developed as a field of study and interest in its own right, efforts have been made to record its history and to establish a research agenda to strengthen its position as a discipline in the wider work of museums. == History == === Non-formal education === In his first report as the first Assistant Secretary of State for Education and Culture during [[John F. Kennedy]]'s administration, in 1968, [[Philip H. Coombs]] emphasized the increment of the educative needs of the world’s population after World War II. In it, he mentions the diversity of non-formal education activities that constitute, or should constitute an important complement to formal education to the total educational efforts of any country.Pastor Homs, Ma. Inmaculada (2001). «La necesidad de planificación y evaluación educativas en la educación no formal. Algunas propuestas». ''Educació i Cultura'': 14, 87-89. To Coombs, non-formal education had the potential to satisfy the learning demands of both, individuals and collectivities, because unlike formal and traditional education, which is rigid with its contents and programs, it is flexible and, when planning and designing educational activities, it takes into consideration local variations of culture, economy and society, which counteracts the tendency of developing countries to just imitate education models of developed countries.Pastor Homs, Ma. Inmaculada (2011 [2004]). «1». ''Pedagogía museística. Nuevas perspectivas y tendencias actuales''. Ariel. p. 15. {{ISBN|978-84-344-6974-7}}. In a work written by Coombs in conjunction with M. Ahmed, non-formal education is defined as "...any organized educational activity outside the established formal system—whether operating separately or as an important feature of some broader activity—that is intended to serve identifiable learning clienteles and learning objective".Coombs, Phillips H. and H. Ahmed. ''New Paths To Learning: For Rural Children and Youth'' (en inglés). New York, N.Y.: International Council for Educational Development Publications. p. 11. Afterwards, Coombs and Ahmed add the idea that non-formal education is any systematic educative activity, organized outside from the official framework to facilitate educative experiences for all people, regardless of age, genre, nationality, social, economic or health situation. Throughout his career, Coombs encouraged and impulsed the professional development of people responsible of non-formal education, which will be determining to the development and professionalization of the educative areas in institutions devoted to non-formal education. === Beginnings in art museums of the United States === At the turn of the twentieth century, art museums were very new institutions to the average visitor, who was seen wandering with no clear direction through the galleries, and with no clear idea on how to appreciate and study the exhibitions. In 1906, architect J. Randolph Coolidge Jr. was appointed the temporary director of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. He experimented with a guiding system in the galleries, to help visitors orient themselves throughout their walk across the exhibitions.Burnham, Rika and, Elliot Kai-Kee (2011). «2». ''Teaching in the Art Museum. Interpretation as Experience''(en inglés). J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles. {{ISBN|978-1-60606-058-2}}. An article published in the June bulletin of the museum that same year, features one of the first uses of the term docent and the description of its functions:
"It has been proposed to the Trustees to consider the permanent appointment of one or more persons of intelligence and education who could act as intermediaries between Curators and the many who would be glad to avail themselves of trained instruction in our galleries. Through these docents, as it has been proposed to call them, the heads of departments could instruct many more persons than it would be possible for them to accompany through the galleries; and illustrated lectures upon the collections prepared in the departments might be regularly given by these specially qualified aids both in the Museum and in the class rooms of neighboring schools and colleges."{{Cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/jstor-4423283/4423283_djvu.txt|title=Full text of "The Educational Work of the Museum. Retrospect and Prospect"|website=archive.org|access-date=2016-06-13}}
== Publications == ''Excellence in Practice: Museum Education Principles and Standards''{{cite book|title=Excellence in Practice: Museum Education Principles and Standards|publisher=EdCom, American Association of Museums|url=http://www.edcom.org/Files/Admin/EdComBookletFinalApril805.pdf}} was developed by the Education Committee of the American Association of Museums to help guide and inform the practice of Museum Education. ''The Journal of Museum Education'' (JME)[http://www.museumeducation.info/jme/ JME: The Journal of Museum Education]. Museum Education Roundtable. {{ISSN|1059-8650}}. is a journal covering the theory, training and practice of the museum education field from the Museum Education Roundtable.[http://www.museumeducation.info/ Museum Education Roundtable website]. Articles are written by museum, education, and research professionals. ''The Museum Education Monitor''{{cite web|last=Castle|first=Chris|title=Museum Education Monitor|url=http://www.mccastle.com/Public/MEM.aspx|accessdate=29 February 2012}} was a monthly email newsletter that tracked and recorded research and resources in museum education worldwide. Publication of ''the Museum Education Monitor'' ended in 2015. ''Art Museum Teaching''[http://artmuseumteaching.com/ Art Museum Teaching] is a digitally published resource and collaborative online forum for reflecting on issues of teaching, learning, and experimental practice in the field of art museum education. ''The Journal of Museum Studies''[https://issuu.com/oucollegeofliberalstudies/stacks/6457e9789c03496abbb60fd31876666f Journal of Museum Studies] is an independent, not-for-profit publication dedicated to creating and preserving a digital archive of scholarly articles in the field of museum studies. [[File:The Early Humans in Iran- NMI brochure.jpg|thumb|A brochure published for young visitors by National Museum of Iran]] == See also == * [[Museology]] == References == {{reflist}} * Art Museum Teaching http://artmuseumteaching.com/ * Museum Education Roundtable http://museumeducation.info/ == External links == * [http://www.museum-ed.org/ Museum-Ed], an online organization devoted to meeting the needs of museum educators by providing tools and resources by and for the museum education community * [http://museumeducation.info/ The Museum Education Roundtable], publisher of the ''Journal of Museum Education'' * [http://nycmer.org/ New York City Museum Educators Roundtable], a forum for museum education professionals to address issues of museum and educational interest, exchange and disseminate relevant information and to explore and implement cooperative programming opportunities through roundtable discussions, workshops, and an annual conference. * [http://artmuseumteaching.com/ Art Museum Teaching], a digital community and collaborative online forum for reflecting on issues of teaching, learning, and experimental practice in the field of art museum education. The site's goal is to connect educators, ideas, and resources around a dialogue about shared practice in teaching and learning. {{DEFAULTSORT:Museum Education}} [[Category:Museum education| ]] [[Category:Museology]] [[Category:Cultural education]]

{{Climbing sidebar |image=Bild auf dem Gedenkstein fuer Guellich (retuschiert).jpg |caption=[[Wolfgang Gullich]] climbing in [[Frankenjura]] ([[Germany|DEU]]). }} In [[free climbing]], a '''first ascent''' ('''FA'''), or '''first free ascent''' ('''FFA''') is the first successful, documented climb of a [[Climbing route|route]] or [[boulder]] performed without using equipment such as [[Anchor (climbing)|anchors]], [[quickdraw]]s or [[Dynamic rope|ropes]] for aiding progression or resting. In this article, notable first free ascents of hard routes and boulders are listed. [[Grade (climbing)|Ratings]] on the hardest climbs tend to be speculative, until other climbers have had a chance to complete the routes and a consensus can be reached on the precise [[Grade (climbing)|grade]]. This becomes increasingly difficult as the grade increases, because fewer climbers are capable of repeating the route and passing judgment on its grade. [[File:Adam Ondra climbing Silence, 9c by PAVEL BLAZEK 1-cropped.jpg|thumb|left|250 px|[[Adam Ondra]] climbing [[#Redpointed|''Silence'']], {{Climbing grade|9c}}, in 2017]] == Overview == As of November 2017: * The hardest ascended route ([[#Redpointed|''Silence'']]) has a proposed grade of {{climbing grade|9c}}. It was first ascended by [[Adam Ondra]] in 2017 and no one else has yet repeated it. * The hardest route ever ascended by a woman is [[#PlantaShiva|''La Planta de Shiva'']], graded {{climbing grade|9b}}. [[Angela Eiter]] claimed its first female ascent in 2017 and no other woman has yet repeated it. * The hardest ascended [[Bouldering|boulder problem]] ([[#Boulder problems|''Burden of dreams'']]) has a proposed grade of {{Boulder grade|9A}}. It was first ascended by [[Nalle Hukkataival]] in 2016 and no one else has yet repeated it. * The hardest routes ever successfully climbed [[on-sight]] are graded {{Climbing grade|9a}}. The first [[on-sight]] ascent of a {{Climbing grade|9a}} route ([[#Onsighted|''Estado Critico'']]) was claimed by [[Alex Megos]] in March 2013. The second ([[#Onsighted|''Cabane au Canada'']]) by Adam Ondra in July 2013. No one else has yet onsighted this grade. == Single-[[pitch (climbing)|pitch]] routes == === [[Redpoint (climbing)|Redpointed by men]] === {{climbing grade|9c}} (unconfirmed): :* [[Silence (climb)|''Silence'']] (formerly known as ''Project Hard''){{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BYxqK3NFG6n/?hl=en&taken-by=adam.ondra|title=Silence 9c, Flatanger, Norway|publisher=Instagram|author=Adam Ondra}} - [[Flatanger]] ([[Norway|NOR]]) - September 3, 2017 - First ascent by [[Adam Ondra]], who described it as "much harder than anything else" he had previously done, and cautiously suggested the 9c rating. The route is about 45 m long. The first 20 m are about {{climbing grade|8B}}, followed by three distinct boulder problems: an extremely hard 8C, a "burly 4-move" 8B and a 7C+ with slippery feet. The first one was described by Ondra as the hardest {{Boulder grade|8C}} he ever climbed. It consists of 10 incredibly hard and unusual moves, including single-[[Glossary of climbing terms#finger_jam|finger locks]], climbing upside down and a variation of a [[Glossary of climbing terms#figure four|figure four]] move. {{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/interviews/adam-ondra-climbs-worlds-first-9c-at-flatanger-in-norway.html|title=Interview: Adam Ondra climbs world's first 9c at Flatanger in Norway|editor=planetmountain.com|date=September 4, 2017|access-date=September 4, 2017}} {{web cite|url=https://www.ukclimbing.com/news/item/71256/adam_ondra_climbs_worlds_first_9c_-_project_hard|title=Adam Ondra climbs world's first 9c - Project Hard|publisher=UKClimbing|access-date=September 3, 2017}} {{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/adam-ondra-climbing-towards-the-worlds-first-9c.html|title=Interview: Adam Ondra climbing toward the world's first 9C|editor=planetmountain.com|date=June 26, 2017|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{web cite|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Xmx2gYwsYo|title=Adam Ondra: incredible moves in possible 9c|editor=Youtube|date=September 14, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{web cite|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HDlsH3AcHGA|title=Adam Ondra trying the first crux of Project Hard|editor=Youtube|date=September 14, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{web cite|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PVkidzoiJ50#t=2.452307|title=Adam Ondra on the second crux of Project Hard|editor=Youtube|date=September 14, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{web cite|url=https://www.climbing.com/people/adam-ondra-the-future-of-climbing/|title=Adam Ondra: the future of climbing|editor=climbing.com|date=June 7, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{climbing grade|9b+}}: :*''Change'' - [[Flatanger]] ([[Norway|{{ISO 3166 code-3|Norway}}]]) - October 4, 2012 - First ascent by [[Adam Ondra]], who claimed it to be the hardest ascent in history :* ''La Dura Dura'' - [[Oliana]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - February 7, 2013 - First ascent by [[Adam Ondra]]. Route bolted by [[Chris Sharma]], who repeated the ascent one month later and confirmed the grade. :*''Vasil Vasil'' - [[Brno]] ([[Czech Republic|CZE]]) - December 5, 2013{{Cite news|url=https://www.climbing.com/news/ondra-completes-third-5-15c-first-ascent/|title=Ondra Completes Third 5.15c First Ascent|work=Climbing Magazine|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en-us}} - First Ascent by Adam Ondra. His third first ascent of the grade. :*''Perfecto Mundo'' - [[Margalef]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - May 9, 2018 - First ascent by [[Alexander Megos]]. Route bolted by [[Chris Sharma]]. {{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/alexander-megos-frees-perfecto-mundo-9b-plus-at-margalef.html|title=Alexander Megos frees Perfecto Mundo 9b+ at Margalef|editor=planetmountain.com|date=May 9, 2018|access-date=May 9, 2018}} {{climbing grade|9b}}: :* ''Akira'' - Vilhonneur cave ([[Périgord]], [[France|{{ISO 3166 code-3|France}}]]) - June 06, 1995 - First ascent by [[Fred Rouhling]]. He proposed a grade of {{climbing grade|9B}}, but the route is still unrepeated and its grade is not confirmed.{{cite web|url=http://novebi.ning.com/group/eauxclaires/forum/topics/akira-vilhonneur-cave?xg_source=activity|title=Akira, Vilhonneur cave}} :* ''Chilam Balam'' - [[Villanueva del Rosario]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - July 4, 2003 - Unconfirmed{{cite web|url=http://climbingnarc.com/2011/04/adam-ondra-makes-quick-work-of-chilam-balam/|title=Adam Ondra makes quick work of Chilam Balam|publisher=ClimbingNarc}} first ascent claimed by Bernabè Fernandez. He proposed a rating of {{climbing grade|5.15c}}{{cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/andalusiadream/|publisher=Climbing Magazine|title=Andalusia Dreamin'|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310033737/http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/andalusiadream/|archivedate=2011-03-10|df=}} but the route was later repeated by [[Adam Ondra]], who graded it as a "low end" {{climbing grade|5.15b}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?keyid=38067|publisher=Planet Mountain|title=Interview with Adam Ondra after climbing Chilam Balam}} :* ''Jumbo Love'' - [[Clark Mountain (California)|Clark Mountain]] ([[Mojave National Preserve]], [[United States|USA]]) - September 11, 2008 - First ascent by [[Chris Sharma]]. Widely considered the world's first 9b{{By whom?|date=September 2018}}. This route is {{convert|250|ft|m|abbr=on|adj=mid|long}}. Sharma has called it his hardest ascent to date. In climbing it, he skipped up to three clips in a row due to the difficult sequences, which resulted in falls of {{convert|70|ft|m|abbr=on}} or more.{{cite web|url= http://climbingnarc.com/2008/09/chris-sharmas-jumbo-love-515b|title=Chris Sharma’s 'Jumbo Love' (5.15b)|publisher=ClimbingNarc}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bigupproductions.com/#/blog/399/|title=Jumbo Love|publisher=Big Up Productions}}{{cite web |url=http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/sharma_redpoints_clark_mountain_project/ |title=Sharma Redpoints Clark Mountain Project |accessdate=2008-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080914170540/http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/sharma_redpoints_clark_mountain_project/ |archivedate=September 14, 2008 |df= }} Repeated by [[Ethan Pringle]], May 2015.{{cite web|title=Ethan Pringle Repeats Jumbo Love|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/ethan-pringle-repeats-jumbo-love-5-15b/|website=Climbing.com|publisher=Climbing Magazine}}{{cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/andrada515b|title=Andrada Calls New Link-Up 5.15b|publisher=Climbing.com}} [[File:Chris Sharma Climbing in Yangshuo, China.jpg|thumb|250 px|[[Chris Sharma]] climbing in [[Yangshuo]] ([[China|CHI]])]] {{climbing grade|9a+}}: :* ''Open Air'' - [[Schleierfall|Schleier Waterfall]] ([[Austria|AUT]]) - 1996 - First ascent by [[Alexander Huber]], who initially proposed a 9a rating. Heralded as the world's hardest route upon completion, the route was first repeated twelve years later by [[Adam Ondra]], who upgraded it to 9a+, trying to fit the grade to the "new school" rating conventions.{{cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/adam-ondra-open-air-and-hotel-supramonte.html|title=Adam Ondra Open Air and Hotel Supramonte|publisher=Planet Mountain}} According to [[Alexander Huber]],{{cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/alpinism/alexander-huber-interview.html|title=Alexander Huber interview|publisher=Planet Mountain}} the route is at least as difficult as ''[[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla]]'', first climbed by him in 1994. Those who doubt that the original version of ''La Rambla'' is 9a+ (including Huber), might consider ''Open Air'' to be the first 9a+ in history. :* ''[[Realization (climb)|Biographie]]'' - Montagne de [[Céüse]] ([[France|FRA]]) - July 2001 - First ascent by [[Chris Sharma]]. Heralded as world's first 9a+ upon completion, because at that time [[Alexander Huber|Huber]]'s ''Open Air'' was still considered to be a 9a route (see above).{{cite web|url=http://www.camp4.com/news/index.php?newsid=117 |title=Chris Sharma climbs Realization (Biographie extension)! |publisher=Camp4 |date=2006-10-05 |accessdate=2012-01-30}} :* ''[[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla Extension]]'' - [[Siurana (Tarragona)|Siurana]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - {{convert|41|m|ft}} long extended version of [[Alexander Huber]]'s route [[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla]], obtained by Dani Andrada by linking Huber's route to another route nearby, via a traverse - March 8, 2003 - First ascent by [[Ramón Julián Puigblanque]], after more than forty failed attempts. Puigblanque proposed a 9a+ rating, later confirmed by many other repeaters. {{climbing grade|9a}}: :* ''[[Action Directe (climb)|Action Directe]]'' - [[Frankenjura]] ([[Germany|{{ISO 3166 code-3|Germany}}]]) - 1991 - First 9a in history, by [[Wolfgang Gullich]]. Still described as one of the hardest routes worldwide. Originallly graded 8c+, it is now widely considered to be a challenging 9a.{{Cite web|url=http://www.frankenjura.com/klettern/poi/7555|title=Action directe|publisher=frankenjura.com|accessdate=11 June 2013|language=German}} :* ''[[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla]]'' - [[Siurana (Tarragona)|Siurana]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - 1994 - First ascent by [[Alexander Huber]], who graded it {{climbing grade|8c+}}. Based on its similarity with ''[[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla Extension]]'', a {{convert|6|m|ft}} longer version of the same route, La Rambla might be considered to be the world's first 9a+, but Huber would probably disagree. In his opinion, both routes are "not harder than" [[Wolfgang Gullich]]'s ''Action Directe'', the word's first 9a, which in 1994 was still rated 8c+. In 2003, [[Ramón Julián Puigblanque]] climbed both routes and graded them 9a+. Since the additional 6 meters of La Rambla Extension were much easier than La Rambla's [[Crux (climbing)|crux]],{{cite web |url=https://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/hframon/ |title=Statement of Youth (interview with Puigblanque) |accessdate=2017-08-10 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517003058/https://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/hframon/ |archivedate=2008-05-17 |df= }} Puigblanque believed that they did not increase the difficulty of the ascent enough to justify an higher rating. :* ''Bain de Sang'' Saint-Loup ([[Pompaples]], [[Switzerland|SUI]]) - 2012 - First 9a female ascent in history by [[Josune Bereziartu]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/josune-bereziartu-climbs-first-female-9a.html|title=Josune Bereziartu climbs first female 9a}} First ascent by [[Fred Nicole]], 1993. Third 9a route in the world. {{climbing grade|8c+}}: :* ''Hubble'' - Raven Tor ([[United Kingdom|GBR]]) - June 14, 1990 - First 8c+ in history, by [[Ben Moon (rock climber)|Ben Moon]].{{web cite|url=http://desnivel.com/personajes/entrevista-a-ben-moon|title=Entrevista a Ben Moon|editor=desnivel.com|date=June 25, 2001|access-date=January 23, 2012}} Due to failed attempts from some of the world's best climbers, upgrading to 9a was suggested.{{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?l=2&keyid=39015|title=Adam Ondra, the routes I cannot climb!|work=planetmountain.com |year=2015 |accessdate=June 11, 2015}} However, [[Alex Megos]], after repeating it in 2016, stated that this was neither one of his hardest, nor one of his easiest 8c+ routes.{{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/interviews/alexander-megos-climbs-hubble-the-raven-tor-interview.html|title=Alexander Megos climbs Hubble. The Raven Tor interview|date=June 3, 2016|access-date=August 3, 2017}} {{climbing grade|8c}}: :* ''Wallstreet'' - [[Frankenjura]] ([[Germany|DEU]]) - 1987 - First 8c in history, by [[Wolfgang Gullich]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.frankenjura.com/klettern/poi/7618|title=Wallstreet|publisher=frankenjura.com|accessdate=June 11, 2013|language=German}} {{climbing grade|8b+}}: :* ''Ravage'' - [[Basel]] ([[Switzerland|CH]]) - 1985 - First 8b+/c in history, bolted by [[Wenzel Vodicka]] but first ascended by [[Antoine Le Menestrel]].{{cite book |author1=Patrick Andrey|author2=Andreas Luisier|author3=Mike Tscharner |title=Fluebible: Kletterführer Basler Jura : Kletterrouten, Boulderprobleme, Eisfälle |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vOveAQAACAAJ |year=1997 |publisher=Dynamo Productions |isbn=978-3-9521468-0-4}} Repeated in 2009 by [[Adam Ondra]] and in 2017 by [[Alex Megos]].{{web cite|url=https://www.redbull.com/ch-de/helveticlimb-alexander-megos|title=Alex Megos Helveticlimb}} :* ''Punks in the Gym'' - [[Mount Arapiles]] ([[Australia|AUS]]) - 1985 - First 8b+ in history, by [[Wolfgang Gullich]]. {{climbing grade|8b}}: :* ''Kanal im Rücken'' - [[Frankenjura]] ([[Germany|DEU]]) - 1984 - First 8b in history, by [[Wolfgang Gullich]]. [[File:Action Directe 11 (9a), Foto Jorgos Megos.JPG|thumb|250 px|[[Alex Megos]] climbing ''[[Action Directe (climb)|Action Directe]]'' in [[Frankenjura]] ([[Germany|DEU]]), 2014]] === [[Redpoint (climbing)|Redpointed]] by women === {{climbing grade|9b}}: :* ''La Planta de Shiva'' - [[Villanueva del Rosario]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - October 22, 2017 - World's first female ascent of a 9b route, by [[Angela Eiter]].{{cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/interviews/angela-eiter-the-first-woman-to-climb-9b-interview.html|title=Interview with Angela Eiter, the first woman to climb 9b|editor=Planet Mountain|accessdate=24 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/angela-eiter-climbs-historic-first-female-9b-with-la-planta-de-shiva-in-spain.html|title=Angela Eiter climbs historic first female 9b|editor=Planet Mountain|accessdate=23 October 2017}} First ascent by [[Adam Ondra]] in 2011. The grade was confirmed by [[Jakob Schubert]] in 2016. {{climbing grade|9a+}}: :* ''[[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla Extension]]'' - [[Siurana (Tarragona)|Siurana]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - February 26, 2017 - World's first female ascent of a 9a+ route, by [[Margo Hayes]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.up-climbing.com/en/falesia/news/32682|title=Margo Hayes, first female 9a+!!|editor=Up Climbing}}{{cite web|url=http://www.up-climbing.com/en/falesia/news/Margo-Hayes-su-La-Rambla-primo-9a--femminile-al-mondo|title=Margo Hayes on La Rambla, first female 9a+ (video)|editor=Up Climbing}} First ascent by [[Ramon Julian Puigblanque]] in 2003 (see above). The grade was confirmed by many repeaters. {{climbing grade|9a}}: :* ''Bain de Sang'' - Saint Loup ([[Switzerland|SUI]]) - October 29, 2002 - World's first female ascent of a 9a route, by [[Josune Bereziartu]], after 15/20 trials. First ascent by [[Fred Nicole]] in 1993. Third 9a route in the world. The grade was confirmed by many repeaters.{{Cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/josune-bereziartu-climbs-first-female-9a.html|title=Josune Bereziartu climbs first female 9a (interview)|editor=Planet Mountain}} === [[Onsight]]ed === {{climbing grade|9A}}: :* ''Estado Critico'' - Siurana ([[Spain|ESP]]) - 24 March 2013 - First 9a onsight in history by [[Alex Megos]]. :* ''Cabane au Canada'' - Rawyl ([[Switzerland|SUI]]) - 9 July 2013 - by [[Adam Ondra]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.ukclimbing.com/news/item.php?id=68197|title=La cabane au Canada, 9a, onsight by Ondra|publisher=ukclimbing.com|author=Björn Pohl|date=9 July 2013|accessdate=10 July 2013}} :* ''Il Domani'' - Baltzola ([[Spain|ESP]]) - 3 May 2014 - by [[Adam Ondra]]. {{climbing grade|8C+}}: :* ''Bizi Euskaraz'' - [[Etxauri]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - December 11, 2007 - First 8c+ onsight in history by [[Patxi Usobiaga]]. Project by Ekaitz Maiz.{{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/News/shownews1.lasso?l=1&keyid=35934|title=Patxi Usobiaga show: Bizi euskaraz primo 8c+ a vista del mondo|editor=planetmountain.com|date=December 13, 2007|access-date=January 8, 2012}} :* ''Kidetasunaren balio erantsia'' - [[Etxauri]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - 6 March 2011 - Second 8c+ onsight in history, by Adam Ondra.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kairn.com/news_escalade_74602.adam-ondra-deuxieme-homme-reussir-8c-vue.html|title=Adam Ondra, deuxième homme à réussir du 8c+ à vue (édité)|work=Kairn.com|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=7 October 2012|language=fr}}[http://desnivel.com/escalada-roca/adam-ondra-8c-mas--a-vista-en-etxauri Adam Ondra, 8c+ on-sight at Etxauri] {{climbing grade|8C}}: :* ''White Zombi'', Baltzola Cave ([[Spain|ESP]]) - October 6, 2004 - World's first 8c onsight, by Yuji Hirayama.{{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/hirayama-worlds-first-8c-on-sight.html|title=Yuji Hirayama world's first 8c on-sight!}} === [[Free solo climbing|Free-solo]] climbed === There are few climbers who have free-soled in the [[Grade_(climbing)|5.14 grade]] range. This list does not include "highball" boulder ascents because the climbers here did not use any padding or spotters. There is some debate on the blurred line between "highball" [[bouldering]] and short free solo climbs.{{web cite|url=http://www.allclimbing.com/archive/2009/01/kevin-jorgeson-sends-ambrosia-and-blurs-line-between-highball-and-free-solo/|title=Kevin Jorgeson sends Ambrosia and blurs line between highball and free solo}} {{climbing grade|8C}}: :* ''Darwin Dixit'' - Length: {{convert|15|m|ft|}} - [[Margalef]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - March 2008 - The first 8c free solo, by [[Dave MacLeod]].{{web cite|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/macleod-solos-514b-in-spain/|title=MacLeod solos 5.14b in Spain}} {{climbing grade|8B+}}: :* ''Kommunist'' - Length: {{convert|22|m|ft|}} - [[Tyrol]] ([[Austria|AUT]]) - 2004 - The first 8b+ free solo, by [[Alexander Huber]].{{web cite|url=http://www.alpinist.com/doc/web08x/wfeature-solo-huber|title=Huber solos 5.14a in Austria}} === Hardest projects=== [[Chris Sharma]] is currently working on an extremely ambitious project that in his opinion may turn out to be harder than {{climbing grade|9b+}}: :* ''Le blond'' - [[Oliana]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - Project by Chris Sharma, immediately to the right of ''La Dura Dura'' (world's first confirmed 9b+). {{web cite|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YwODjN5sKLI&vl=es|title=Chris Sharma, The Blonde, 9C|editor=Youtube|date=September 8, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/chris-sharma-in-le-blond-project-at-oliana.html|title=Chris Sharma in Le Blond project at Oliana|editor=planetmountain.com|date=August 26, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} Named after [[Patrick Edlinger]], who passed away while Sharma was bolting the route. [[File:Es pontas 2.jpg|thumbnail|[[Es Pontàs]], a natural arch in the coast of [[Mallorca]]]] == [[Deep-water solo]] routes == {{Climbing grade|9b}} (unconfirmed): :* ''Alasha'' - [[Mallorca]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - September 12, 2016. First ascent by [[Chris Sharma]], who estimated its grade based on the effort it took to climb it without rope: "If it had bolts on it, it probably wouldn’t be a 9b (5.15b). But when you’re 60 feet up with no bolts, it takes the same amount of effort.” {{cite web|url=http://www.rockandice.com/climbing-news/chris-sharma-sends-Alasha-5-15-deep-water-solo-project|title=Chris Sharma Sends Five-Year 5.15 Deep Water Solo Project|publisher=Rock and Ice|date=September 29, 2016|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} Sharma named the route after his daughter, Alana Sharma. {{Climbing grade|9a+}}: :* ''[[Es Pontàs]]'' - [[Mallorca]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - September 26, 2007. First ascent by [[Chris Sharma]]. Repeated by Jernej Kruder in November 2016. It features a {{convert|7|ft|m}} dyno that took Sharma over 50 attempts to stick. {{cite web|url=http://www.freakclimbing.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1364 |title=Chris Sharma sends his mega Arch Project in Mallorca - News |publisher=FreakClimbing.com |date=2006-09-28 |accessdate=2012-01-30}} {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yOQYlheOLy4||title=Reel Rock: King Lines, Part 2|publisher=Youtube|date=September 9, 2014|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} [[File:Organ Pipes, Mt Wellington - Battlements, Bryan Kennedy.jpg|thumb|[[Bryan Kennedy (climber)|Bryan Kennedy]] free soloing the ''Kennedy variant'' to the Organ Pipes, [[Mount Wellington (Tasmania)|Mount Wellington]] ([[Australia|AUS]]), 1977]] == Multi-[[pitch (climbing)|pitch]] routes == === [[Redpoint (climbing)|Redpointed]] === {{climbing grade|9A}}: :* ''The Dawn Wall'' - [[El Capitan]] ([[Yosemite]], [[United States|USA]]) - Height: 3,000 feet (915 meters) - 32 pitches, at least two of which graded {{climbing grade|9A}}. Described as the hardest big wall in the world. ::: January 14, 2015 - Redpointed by [[Tommy Caldwell]] and [[Kevin Jorgeson]] in 19 days, after 7 years of practicing.{{cite web|last=Bello|first=Marisol|date=January 15, 2015|title=Yosemite free-climbers reach top of El Capitan|publisher=usatoday.com|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/01/14/yosemite-free-climbers/21737187/}}{{cite web |last=Bisharat|first=Andrew|date=January 15, 2015|title=Summiting Yosemite's Dawn Wall, Climbers Make History|website=news.nationalgeographic.com|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2015/01/150114-climbing-yosemite-caldwell-jorgeson-capitan/|accessdate=2015-01-15}} ::: November 21, 2016 - Redpointed by [[Adam Ondra]] in only 8 days, after a few weeks of practicing.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/11/23/czech-free-climber-adam-ondra-scales-yosemite-rock-wall-record/ Czech free-climber Adam Ondra scales Yosemite rock wall in record time] ([[The Daily Telegraph]]) Ondra was the first person to [[Lead climbing|lead]] every pitch.{{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/adam-ondra-completes-dawn-wall/|title=Adam Ondra Completes Dawn Wall|work=Climbing|accessdate=22 November 2016}} {{climbing grade|8b}}: :* The Nose - [[El Capitan]] ([[Yosemite]], [[United States|USA]]) - Height: 3,000 feet (915 meters) - 31 pitches one of which is graded at 5.14a/b. Described as one of the most important ascents in climbing history.{{Cite journal|last=Caldwell|first=Tommy|date=2008|title=Mountain Profile: The Captain|url=|journal=Alpinist|volume=25|pages=46-47|via=}}{{Cite news|url=|title=Climb Like a Girl|last=Hightower|first=Elizabeth|date=4 March 2007|work=New York Times|access-date=}} 1993 − First to free climb, [[Lynn Hill]] with partner Brooke Sandahl. Was not repeated for 10 years after their ascent. === [[Free solo climbing|Free-solo]] climbed === {{climbing grade|7c+}}: :* ''Freerider'': [[El Capitan]] ([[Yosemite]], [[United States|USA]]) - Height: 3,000 feet (915 meters) - June 3, 2017 - First free solo ascent on El Capitan, and world's hardest multi-pitch free solo by [[Alex Honnold]]. Time: 3 hours, 56 minutes{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/adventure/features/athletes/alex-honnold/most-dangerous-free-solo-climb-yosemite-national-park-el-capitan/|title=Exclusive: Climber Completes the Most Dangerous Rope-Free Ascent Ever|date=3 June 2017|publisher=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/06/us/california-today-alex-honnold-el-capitan-climb.html|title=California Today: An ‘Incomprehensible’ Climb in Yosemite|last=Mcphate|first=Mike|date=2017-06-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-06-06|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{web cite|url=https://www.climbing.com/videos/the-first-video-of-alex-honnolds-freerider-free-solo/|title=Video of Alex Honnold's Freerider}} [[File:Christian Core on Gioia.jpg|thumb|[[Christian Core]] on ''Gioia'' ([[Varazze]], [[Italy|ITA]]), first {{Boulder grade|8C+}} boulder in history, 2008]] [[File:Midnight Lightning yosemite.jpg|thumb|Michael Rael Armas on ''Midnight Lightning'', [[Camp 4 (Yosemite)|Camp 4]] ([[Yosemite National Park]], [[United States|USA]]), one of the world's most famous bouldering problems]] == [[Bouldering|Boulder problems]] == {{Boulder grade|9A}} (unconfirmed): :*''Burden of Dreams'' - Lappnor ([[Finland|{{ISO 3166 code-3|Finland}}]]) - October 2016 - Grade proposed by [[Nalle Hukkataival]] after several years of trials. During these years, Hukkataival "very quickly" solved several 8C and 8C+ boulder problems throughout the world, including ''Gioia'' (see below). Compared to these other problems, ''Burden of Dreams'' felt "way way harder".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4DQf7aGO1uU|title=Interview: Nalle Hukkataival - Burden of Dreams (9A bloc)|publisher=Relais Vertical|accessdate=2 September 2017}} {{Boulder grade|8C+}}: :* ''Gioia'' - Varezze ([[Italy|ITA]]) - 2008 - First ascent by Italian boulderer [[Christian Core]], who first proposed 8C, "to play things safe". In 2011, [[Adam Ondra]] repeated the ascent and wholeheartedly proposed the 8C+ grade, describing the boulder as one of the hardest in the world, together with ''Terranova'' (see below).{{cite web |url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/adam-ondra-the-pure-gioia-interview.html|title=Adam Ondra, the pure Gioia interview|publisher=Planetmountain|date=7 December 2011 |accessdate=1 August 2017}} :* ''Terranova'' - [[Holstejn]] ([[Moravsky Kras]], [[Czech Republic|CZE]]) - 10 November 2011 - First ascent by [[Adam Ondra]].{{cite web |url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/adam-ondra-frees-terranova-8c-.html|title=Adam ondra frees Terranova 8C+|date=15 November 2011 |accessdate=1 August 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ukclimbing.com/news/item.php?id=64987|title=8C+ boulder by Ondra|work=UKClimbing.com|author=Björn Pohl|accessdate=7 October 2012}} {{Boulder grade|8C}}: :* ''The story of two worlds'' - [[Cresciano]] ([[Switzerland|SUI]]) - January 2005 - First confirmed 8C in history, by [[Dave Graham (climber)|Dave Graham]]. {{cite news |url=http://www.freakclimbing.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=389|title=Dave Graham, 'The story of two worlds' his new 8C and his new grading philosophy|publisher=FreakClimbing|date=19 January 2005|accessdate=1 August 2017}} Five years earlier, [[Fred Nicole]] had proposed 8C for ''Dreamtime'', on the other side of the same boulder, but most repeaters downgraded it to 8b+ (see below). :* ''The Game'' - [[Boulder, Colorado]] ([[United States|USA]]) - 2010 - First ascent by [[Daniel Woods]], who originally graded it {{Boulder grade|8C+}}.{{cite news |url=http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?l=2&keyid=37243 |title=Daniel Woods plays The Game Fb8C+ |publisher=PlanetMountain |date=12 February 2010 |accessdate=11 August 2013}} Second ascent in 2013 by Carlo Traversi, who proposed {{Boulder grade|8C}}.{{cite news |url=http://climbingnarc.com/2011/03/carlo-traversi-repeats-the-game-v15-in-boulder-canyon/|title=Carlo Traversi repeats The Game (V15) in boulder canyon|publisher=Climbing Narc|date= March 12, 2011||accessdate=1 August 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.dpmclimbing.com/articles/view/carlo-traversi-sends-game-v1516 |title=Carlo Traversi Sends The Game (V15/16) |publisher=DPM Climbing |date=12 March 2011 |accessdate=11 August 2013}} :* ''Lucid Dreaming'' - [[Bishop, California]] ([[United States|USA]]) - 2010 - First ascent by [[Paul Robinson (climber)|Paul Robinson]], who initially graded it {{Boulder grade|8C+}},{{cite news |url=http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?l=2&keyid=37330 |title=Lucid Dreaming, new extreme boulder problem at the Buttermilks, Bishop |publisher=PlanetMountain |date=31 March 2010 |accessdate=11 August 2013}} and later downgraded it. In 2010, together with ''The game'' (see above), this was considered to be one of the world's most challenging boulders. Second ascent by [[Daniel Woods]], who confirmed the {{Boulder grade|8C}} grade.{{cite web |url=http://climbingnarc.com/2014/01/daniel-woods-does-repeat-lucid-dreaming/ |title=Daniel Woods Does Repeat Lucid Dreaming |publisher=Climbing Narcissist |date=28 January 2014 |accessdate=30 January 2014}} {{Boulder grade|8b+}}: :* ''Dreamtime'' - [[Cresciano]] ([[Switzerland|SUI]]) - October 28, 2000 - First ascent by [[Fred Nicole]], who proposed an 8C rating, making it the first unconfirmed 8C boulder in history. In 2002, [[Dave Graham (climber)|Dave Graham]] repeated it by finding a different solution. He used a [[Glossary of climbing terms#heel hook|heel-hook]] to make the brutal start sequence easier, and downgraded the problem to easy 8b+. Most of the following repeaters, including [[Adam Ondra]], [[Chris Sharma]], and [[Daniel Woods]] adopted Graham's solution and agreed with him about the grade.{{cite web |url=https://www.99boulders.com/hardest-boulder-problems|title=Hardest boulder problems|publisher=99boulders|date=October 26, 2016|accessdate=August 1, 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://community.mammut.ch/t5/Mammut-Magazine/The-Classics-Dreamtime/ba-p/2875|title=The classics - Dreamtime|publisher=Mammut Magazine|date=July 5, 2017|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} Notable exceptions are [[Jan Hojer]] and [[Christian Core]], who confirmed the 8C rating.[https://www.8a.nu/?IncPage=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.8a.nu%2Fuser%2FProfile.aspx%3FUserId%3D16898 Hojer Comments about Dreamtime on 8a.nu] {{Boulder grade|7B+}}: :* ''[[Midnight Lightning (bouldering)|Midnight Lightning]]'' - [[Camp 4 (Yosemite)|Camp 4]] ([[Yosemite National Park]], [[United States|USA]]) - 1978 - First ascent by [[Ron Kauk]]. First female ascent by [[Lynn Hill]], 1998. {{Cite web |url=http://adventure.nationalgeographic.com/2008/09/yosemite/climbing-photosynth-text |title=Yosemite in 3-D |author=Corey Rich |date=August 2008 |accessdate=9 May 2013 |publisher=National Geographic}} {{Cite web |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1064893/5/index.htm |title=On The Rocks, Kauk Is It |author=Sam Moses |publisher=Sport Illustrated |date=2 June 1986 |accessdate=9 May 2013}} {{Cite web |url=https://www.mountainproject.com/v/midnight-lightning/105835104 |title=Midnight Lightning - Mountain Project}} Thirtynine years after its solution, it has been described as one of the world's most famous bouldering problems, together with ''Dreamtime'' (see above). {{Cite web |url=http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?l=2&keyid=40853 |title=Midnight Lightning bolt, the icon of free climbing in Yosemite disappears for a day |publisher=planetmountain.com |date=7 May 2013 |accessdate=9 May 2013}} == See also == *[[History of rock climbing]] *[[List of first ascents]] *[[List of highest mountains on Earth#List|List of first ascents on the highest mountains on Earth]] *[[Exploration of the High Alps]] *[[List of first ascents in the Sierra Nevada (U.S.)]] *[[List of first ascents in the Cordillera Blanca]] == References == {{Reflist|refs= {{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/ondra-puts-down-la-dura-dura-5-15c/|title=Ondra Puts Down La Dura Dura (5.15c)|work=Climbing|accessdate=7 February 2013}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/ondra-5-15c-norway/|title=Adam Ondra Climbs 5.15c in Norway|work=Climbing|author=Dougald MacDonald|date=4 October 2012|accessdate=7 October 2012}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/it/notizie/interviste/alexander-megos-lintervista-dopo-il-primo-9a-a-vista-mondiale.html|title=First 9A onsight by Alex Mesgos}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/nalle-hukkataival-climbs-burden-of-dreams-and-proposes-worlds-first-9a-boulder-problem.html|title=Nalle Hukkataival climbs Burden of Dreams and proposes world's first 9a boulder problem|editor=Planet Mountain}} }} == External links == * {{Cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/it/notizie/arrampicata/levoluzione-dellarrampicata-libera.html|title=The evolution of free climbing|language=Italian|publisher=Planet Mountain|author=Maurizio Oviglia|date=December 21, 2012}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.99boulders.com/hardest-boulder-problems|title=Hardest boulder problems|publisher=99boulders|date=October 26, 2016|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} [[Category:Sport climbing]] [[Category:Rock climbing|02]] [[Category:History of sports|Rock]] [[Category:Climbing and mountaineering-related lists]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} The '''Orkney International Science Festival'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-north-east-orkney-shetland-19560265|title=Orkney study sheds light on lives of brown crabs|publisher=BBC News|date=11 September 2012|accessdate=2012-09-12}}</ref> is a [[science festival]] which takes place every September in [[Kirkwall]], [[Orkney|Orkney Islands]], [[Scotland]] and has been running since 1991.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.orkney.com/science-festival |title=Orkney Culture: Orkney Science Festival|publisher=Orkney.com|accessdate=2012-09-12}}</ref>
==2013 Festival== The 2014 Orkney International Science Festival was opened by documentary film-maker [[Alan Ereira]], and featured over 50 events on topics of astronomy, archaeology, the Arctic, the science of a lost city, Vikings, the search for a lost undersea world, ancient catastrophes on Earth, and supermassive black holes. Speakers included astronomer and author Prof. [[Bill Napier]] of Buckingham University, Prof. Bonnie A. Steves of Glasgow Caledonian University, and archaeologist Dr. Cathy Batt from Bradford University.<ref>[http://www.orcadian.co.uk/2013/07/astronomy-archaeology-and-arctic-for-2013-science-festival/ "Astronomy, archaeology and arctic for 2013 Science Festival"], ''The Orcadian,'' 25 July 2013 (retrieved 3 August 2015)</ref>
==2014 Festival== The 2014 festival was opened by the former chief scientist of the [[Discovery Channel]], Professor Steve ‘Jake’ Jacobs.<ref>[http://www.orcadian.co.uk/2014/09/discovery-channel-scientist-to-open-orkney-science-festival/ Discovery Channel scientist to open Orkney Science Festival], '' The Orcadian,'' 4 September 2014 (retrieved 3 August 2015)</ref> Topics of the festival ranged from the origin of life in space, to clues from genetics to the people of the Viking Age.<ref>Orkney International Science Festival, [http://oisf.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/OISF-2014-programme.pdf Programme 2014] (retrieved 3 August 2015)</ref>
==2015 Festival== 2015 marks the 25th festival. In 2015, the "International Year of Light" will be a theme of the festival, featuring a conversation with Nobel Prizewinner [[Peter Higgs]], and with highlights including the Higgs boson, Einstein’s universe, Maxwell’s waves, exploring Mars and Venus, our changing weather, and cracking the cancer code.<ref>Orkney International Science Festival, [https://web.archive.org/web/20160304070935/http://oisf.org/programme-2015/ Programme 2015] (retrieved 3 August 2015)</ref>
==Notes and references==
{{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.oisf.org/ Orkney International Science Festival]
