{{Scotland-stub}} {{festival-stub}}

The '''Queen's English Society''' is a charity that aims to keep the English language safe from perceived declining standards.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.queens-english-society.com/|title=Cover Page - The Queen's English Society |author=The Queen's English Society |accessdate=3 October 2010}}</ref> The president of the Queen's English Society is Bernard Lamb, a former [[Reader (academic rank)|reader]] in [[genetics]] at [[Imperial College]].
In June 2012 the Society announced its closure because of declining participation,<ref name="Guardian 4 June 2012">{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Lewis|title=Queen's English Society says enuf is enough, innit?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2012/jun/04/queens-english-society-enuf-innit|accessdate=4 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=4 June 2012}}</ref><ref name="Independent 4 June 2012">{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Lewis|title=Lack of interest spells the end for the Queen's English Society|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/lack-of-interest-spells-the-end-for-the-queens-english-society-7814791.html|accessdate=July 26, 2012|newspaper=The Independent|date=June 4, 2012}}</ref> but it continued to exist, as volunteers filled the committee in September 2012.<ref name="QES Events">[http://www.queens-english-society.com/events.html Queen's English Society: Events] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120721233925/http://www.queens-english-society.com/events.html |date=July 21, 2012 }} Retrieved July 26, 2012</ref><ref name="Quest111">''Quest'' No. 111, Summer 2012</ref>
==History== The Queen's English Society was founded in 1972 by Joe Clifton, an Oxford graduate and schoolteacher. The Society's meetings were held in [[Arundel]], and members wrote to newspapers and broadcasters, pointing out perceived linguistic errors and instances of ambiguous spoken English.
The Society claims to be concerned about the education of children. It believes that teachers should be trained to spot certain errors in English usage. In 1988, the Society delivered a petition to the then Secretary of State for Education and Science, [[Kenneth Baker, Baron Baker of Dorking|Kenneth Baker]], urging him "to introduce the compulsory study of formal grammar, including parsing and sentence analysis, into the school curriculum".
The objectives of the Society, as expressed in its constitution, are "to promote the maintenance, knowledge, understanding, development and appreciation of the English language as used both colloquially and in literature; to educate the public in its correct and elegant usage; and to discourage the intrusion of anything detrimental to clarity or euphony”.
On 4 June 2012, after a general meeting of the society attracted no nominations to replace retiring officers of the Society, chairman Rhea Williams announced that the society would cease to exist,<ref name="Guardian 4 June 2012" /><ref name="Independent 4 June 2012" /> but after new committee members volunteered, the Society was able to continue.<ref name="Quest111"/>
==The QES Academy of the English Language==
In June 2010 the QES announced that it had formed an Academy of English, a language reference website. The founder of the academy was quoted as saying that: "At the moment, anything goes. Let’s set down a clear standard of what is good, correct, proper English. Let’s have a body to sit in judgment."<ref name="Times 7 Jun 2010" />
The Academy attracted widespread press coverage, some positive and some negative, and the QES enjoyed a surge in membership. In September 2010 the QES deleted the "Academy" content from its website, though the Academy was continued by its own board on a separate website,<ref>http://www.queens-english-society.org.uk/{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> which is linked to that of the QES and ''vice versa''.
===Reception=== A ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' opinion piece<ref>[http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/geraldwarner/100042575/we-need-an-academy-of-english-to-save-our-beautiful-language/ "We need an Academy of English to save our beautiful language"], Gerald Warner. ''[[Daily Telegraph]] Education'', 8 June 2010.</ref> had called the QES Academy "both welcome and long overdue. [...] English has been left to fend for itself at a time when it is under unprecedented attack." ''[[The Guardian]]'' believed that the Academy would seek to "protect the language from innovations",<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/science/2010/jun/07/folly-of-embalming-english-language "The folly of preserving English in aspic"], John Mullan, Monday 7 June 2010 ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref> although its members had insisted that it would "mov[e] with the times".<ref name="Times 7 Jun 2010">[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/education/article7145147.ece "Pedants' revolt aims to protect English from the spell of txt spk"] ''The Times'', 7 Jun 2010</ref>
American phoneticist [[Mark Liberman]] called the QES "even more illogical, hypocritical and badly informed than you'd expect them to be".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=2384|title=Language Log|work=upenn.edu|accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref> In the ''[[Baltimore Sun]]'' John E McIntyre wrote: "the peevish combination of shibboleth and superstition about language, combined with a sad, sad little snobbery about their presumed mastery of the language, renders these people [the QES] impervious to reason",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/news/mcintyre/blog/2010/06/speak_proper_or_else.html|title=You Don't Say: Speak proper, or else - English grammar, language, usage and journalism blog by John E. McIntyre - baltimoresun.com|work=baltimoresun.com|accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref> referencing an analysis of their nascent website by [[Stan Carey]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carey|first1=Stan|title=The Queen’s English Society deplores your impurities|url=http://stancarey.wordpress.com/2010/06/11/the-queen%E2%80%99s-english-society-deplores-your-impurities/|website=Sentence First, WorfPress.com|date=11 June 2010}}</ref> Comedian [[David Mitchell (comedian)|David Mitchell]] disliked the "self-appointed" nature of the Academy and asked, "[b]y what authority would they sit in judgment?"<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/jun/13/david-mitchell-comment-is-free "Snakes are evil, but save your venom for the self-appointed language police"], David Mitchell, 13 Jun 2010</ref> The proposal was received with scepticism by ''[[The Economist]]'''s Lane Greene.<ref>[https://www.economist.com/blogs/johnson/2010/06/english_academy ''Johnson'' (''The Economist''): "This Time We Mean It"]</ref>
==Publications== The Society’s quarterly journal, ''Quest'', has been sent to members from 1979. It included articles, letters from members, news, book reviews, puzzles and poems. Books published by the QES include ''The Queen's English: And How to Use It'' by Bernard Lamb, and ''Shakin' the Ketchup Bot'le'', a compilation of articles from ''Quest''.
==See also== * [[Linguistic prescription]] * [[Received Pronunciation]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.queens-english-society.org Queen's English Society homepage] * [http://www.charitycommission.gov.uk/SHOWCHARITY/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithoutPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=272901&SubsidiaryNumber=0 Charity Commission page for the Queen's English Society]

The '''R score''' ('''''cote de rendement au collégial''''', '''''CRC''''' or '''''cote R''''' in [[French language|French]]) is a [[statistics|statistical]] method which classifies [[College education in Quebec|college]] students' academic performances in [[Quebec]]. It is used by Quebec [[university|universities]] for selection purposes.
The R score is in fact a [[standard score|''z''-score]] (Zcol) multiplied by a group dispersion indicator (IDGZ) to which an indicator of group strength (ISGZ) has been added.
:R score = ( (Zcol x IDGZ) + ISGZ + C ) x D , where C = D = 5
The Zcol is the number of standard deviations the student is above the class average and gives an indication of the grade of the student with respect to the grades of other students in the class. The ISGZ is the average high school z-score (Zsec) the group's students obtained on the MEES uniform examination subjects in Secondary 4 and 5. The IDGZ is the standard deviation of the students' Zsec scores. The inclusion of the ISGZ and IDGZ in the determination of the R score allows for a more equitable comparison between students, regardless of their CEGEP's academic rank, although the effectiveness remains in dispute.
The use of the constant C = 5 greatly reduces the possibility of a negative value in the score and the multiplying the sum of all the preceding values by the constant D = 5 ensures the largeness of the score. The R score is defined such that the average is 25. Most R scores fall between 15 and 35, although any real number is a possible R score since the z-scores tend to positive or negative infinity as the standard deviation decreases. To guarantee that a grade of 100 will produce an R score of at least 35, an adjusted Z score formula guaranteed to produce a result above 35 is used. Grades below 50 are not considered when calculating the average and standard deviation of a grade distribution.
An R score is calculated for every course except for Physical Education taken before Fall 2007 or for remedial courses. The final R score is the weighted average of the R score in all courses. In addition, failed courses are given a reduced weight in the overall R score; they are weighted at 25% of the credits in the first semester and subsequently at 50%.
==History== Failed courses have been given a reduced weight since October 2004. Before the Fall 2007 semester, Physical Education courses were not given an R score. Before July 2017, the R score did not include the IDGZ and used calculated the ISG as
:ISG = ( Average grade results of Secondary 4 and 5 of all the group's students - 75 ) / 14.
Also until July 2017, an additional score of 0.5 was added to the overall R score to a student graduating with an [[International Baccalaureate]] degree or a ''DEC (Diplôme d'études collégiales) en Sciences, Lettres et Arts''. The adjustment of Z score using the IDGZ makes this unnecessary.
==Criticism== Firsthand experience suggests that the R score is not as ideal a tool as it was meant to be. A recurring complaint from students is that the ISG does not seem to sufficiently offset the advantage enjoyed by students in weak groups. Such students have the opportunity to obtain grades much higher than the low average of their class, thus earning an elevated Z score, whereas students in strong groups cannot earn such high Z scores. One possible reason for this is that the ISG for a certain course is based on the average of the grades in all high school courses, which may not correlate to the group's strength in that course as much as the average of the grades of similar courses in high school.
Such perceived weaknesses of the R score are particularly worrying, because it is the main and sometimes only criterion considered by Quebec universities during the admissions process. Since the R score is perceived as an absolute measure of a student's academic performance regardless of their College academic rank, differences smaller than 0.5 are often used to discriminate between candidates applying to programs with fixed quotas, such as medicine, pharmacy, dentistry or law.
==External links== *[http://www.bci-qc.ca/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/03-R_Score_what-it-is_what-it-does_BCI-july12-2017.pdf The R Score: What It Is and What It Does] *[http://calculateurcoter.com/en/r-score-calculator R Score calculator] [[Category:Education in Quebec]] [[Category:Student assessment and evaluation]] [[Category:Statistics of education]]

The '''recency illusion''' is the belief or impression that a word or language usage is of recent origin when it is long-established. The term was coined by [[Arnold Zwicky]], a linguist at [[Stanford University]] primarily interested in examples involving words, meanings, phrases, and grammatical constructions.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rickford |first1=John R. |last2=Wasow |first2=Thomas |last3=Zwicky |first3=Arnold |date=2007 |title=Intensive and quotative ''all'': something new, something old |journal=American Speech |doi=10.1215/00031283-2007-001 |volume=82 |issue=1 |pages=3–31}}</ref> However, use of the term is not restricted to linguistic phenomena: Zwicky has defined it simply as, "the belief that things ''you'' have noticed only recently are in fact recent".<ref name=LL02386>{{cite web |last=Zwicky |first=Arnold |date=7 August 2005 |title=Just between Dr. Language and I |website=Language Log |url=http://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/002386.html |accessdate=5 May 2015}}</ref>
According to Zwicky, the illusion is caused by [[selective perception|selective attention]].<ref name="LL02386"/>
==Examples==
Linguistic items prone to the recency illusion include: * "[[Singular they]]": the use of "they," "them," or "their" to reference a singular antecedent without specific [[gender]], as in "someone said they liked the play." Although this usage is often cited as a modern invention, it is quite old.<ref name="MWDU">{{cite book |year=1989 |title=Merriam Webster's Dictionary of English Usage |publisher=Merriam Webster}}</ref> The usage is found, for example, in Shakespeare.<ref>{{cite book |last=Shakespeare |first=William |authorlink=William Shakespeare |date=1594 |title=The Comedy of Errors |chapter=Act IV, Scene 3 |url=http://www.opensourceshakespeare.org/views/plays/play_view.php?WorkID=comedyerrors&Act=4&Scene=3&Scope=scene |quote=There's not a man I meet but doth salute me / As if I were their well-acquainted friend}}</ref> * The phrase "between you and I" (rather than "between you and me"), often viewed today as a [[hypercorrection]], which could also be found occasionally in Early Modern English.<ref name="MWDU" /> * The [[intensifier]] "really," as in "it was a really wonderful experience," and the moderating adverb "pretty," as in "it was a pretty exciting experience." Many people have the impression that these usages are somewhat [[slang]]-like, and have developed relatively recently.{{citation needed |date=November 2014 |reason=need an RS stating that this is the recency illusion -- otherwise this is WP:SYN}} They go back to at least the 18th century, and are commonly found in the works and letters of such writers as [[Benjamin Franklin]]. * "Literally" being used figuratively as an intensifier is often viewed as a recent change, but in fact usage dates back to the 1760s.<ref>{{cite web |last=Zimmer |first=Benjamin |title=Literally: a history |publisher=Language Log |url=http://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/002611.html}}</ref> * "Aks" as a production of [[African American English]] only.{{citation needed |date=November 2014 |reason=need an RS stating that this is the recency illusion -- otherwise this is WP:SYN}} Use of "aks" in place of "ask" dates back to the works of [[Chaucer]] in Middle English, though typically in this context spelled "ax".<ref name="lippi-green">{{cite book |last=Lippi-Green |first=Rosina |date=1997 |title=English with an Accent: Language, Ideology, and Discrimination in the United States |edition=2nd |publisher=Routledge |location=London |isbn=9780415559102}}</ref> * The word "recency" itself. It is commonly used in consumer marketing ("analyze the recency of customer visits")<ref>{{cite web |author=root |date=14 February 2011 |title=Recency, Frequency, Monetary Value (RFM) Definition |publisher=Investopedia |url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/r/rfm-recency-frequency-monetary-value.asp}}</ref> and many think it was coined for that purpose.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} But its first known use was in 1612.<ref>{{MerriamWebsterDictionary|recency}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Frequency illusion]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * {{cite journal |last=Zwicky |first=Arnold |date=17 November 2007 |title=The word: Recency illusion |journal=New Scientist |volume=196 |issue=2630 |page=60 |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg19626302.300-the-word-recency-illusion.html |subscription=yes}}
[[Category:Historical linguistics]]

<!-- Anything listed in the article as "other names" are names for the same section that have been seen on other articles, but should be changed to the one in this boilerplate. --> {{wikisourcepar|Child's Ballads/1}} {{Infobox song | name = Riddles Wisely Expounded | cover = <!--just the file name--> | cover_size = | alt = | border = | caption = | type = | artist = | album = | EP = | language = [[English language|English]] | English_title = | A-side = | B-side = | written = 1450 | published = | released = <!--{{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}}--> | format = | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = Traditional English song, [[Child Ballads|Child Ballad]] | length = | label = | writer = <!--for both music and lyrics--> | composer = | lyricist = | producer = | chronology = | prev_title = <!-- for a singles chronology--> | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = | misc = <!--for use of {{Extra chronology}}, {{Extra track listing}}, {{Extra album cover}}, {{Audio sample}}--> }}
"'''Riddles Wisely Expounded'''" is a traditional English song, dating at least to 1450. It is [[Child Ballads|Child Ballad]] 1 and [[Roud Folk Song Index|Roud]] 161, and exists in several variants.<ref>[[Francis James Child]], [http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/eng/child/ch001.htm "Riddles Wisely Expounded"]</ref> The first known tune was attached to it in 1719.
==Synopsis== In the earliest surviving version of the song,<ref>Child, Additions and corrections to Ballad #1, in the appendix to Volume 5 of ''The English and Scottish Popular Ballads''</ref> ''Inter diabolus et virgo'', "between the devil and the maiden" (mid-15th century), the "foul fiend" proposes to abduct a maiden unless she can answer a series of riddles. The woman prays to Jesus for wisdom, and answers the riddles correctly.
In later versions, a knight puts a woman to test before he marries her (sometimes after seducing her), or a devil disguised as a knight tries to carry her off. The woman knows the answers, and thus either wins the marriage or is free of the devil. In the latter case, the last riddle is often "what is worse than woman?" (the devil).
The riddles vary, but typical ones include *What is longer than the way? -- love *What is deeper than the sea? -- hell *What is louder than the horn? -- thunder *What is sharper than a thorn? -- hunger *What is whiter than milk? -- snow *What is softer than silk? -- down
==Commentary== The motif of riddling in folklore is very ancient, the stories of [[Oedipus]] and [[Samson]] giving two early examples. The particular form used here matches the folktale [[Aarne-Thompson]] type 875 ''The Clever Girl'' where a woman wins a husband by her clever answers to riddles.<ref>Francis James Child, ''The English and Scottish Popular Ballads'', v 1, p 1, Dover Publications, New York 1965</ref> Other tales of this type include ''[[What Is the Fastest Thing in the World?]]'' and ''[[The Wise Little Girl]]''.
In this ballad, the words of each verse are interspersed with a chorus phrase "lay the bent to the bonny broom". [[A. L. Lloyd]] euphemistically describes this as a phrase of "physiological significance", explaining that the word "bent" means a horn.<ref>A. L. Lloyd, ''Folk Song in England'', Paladin, 1975. p.154</ref> "Broom" most likely refers to the [[broom (shrub)|flowering shrub]].
There are many German variants of this ballad,<ref>Francis James Child, ''The English and Scottish Popular Ballads'', v 1, p 1-2, Dover Publications, New York 1965</ref> and a Gaelic form was widespread among both Scots and Irish.<ref>Francis James Child, ''The English and Scottish Popular Ballads'', v 1, p 3, Dover Publications, New York 1965</ref>
===Modern retellings===
*''[[Juniper, Gentian, and Rosemary]]'' by [[Pamela Dean]] * "A Diorama of the Infernal Regions, or the Devil's Ninth Question," by [[Andy Duncan (writer)|Andy Duncan]]
==Music== <!-- Music associated with this song. The song is considered to be the words for the purposes of the rest of the article. -->
===Recordings=== <!-- Other names: "Versions", "Performances", "Modern Adaptions" -->

__NOTOC__ [[Image:Shemahinskaya boyaderka 2.jpg|right|thumb|150px|A dancer from [[Shamakhi]]. [[Grigory Gagarin|G.Gagarin]], mid-19th century]] The '''Shamakhi dancers''' ([[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]]: ''Şamaxı rəqqasələri'') were the principal dancers of the entertainment groups that existed in [[Shamakhi]] ([[Azerbaijan]]) up to the late 19th century. These groups worked similarly to [[tawaif]]s. [[Russia]]n painter [[Grigory Gagarin]] who lived in the [[Caucasus]] in 1840–1855 depicted the Shamakhi dancers in a series of paintings, in which he referred to them as ''bayaderki''[http://www.azeri.ru/az/cultur/359/ Ими восхищался Дюма] by Emil Karimov and Mehpara Aliyeva. ''Azeri.ru'' (баядерки; sg. ''bayaderka'' – баядерка; originally the Portuguese term ''balliadera'' borrowed into Russian and other European languages via French (''bayadère'') and initially used to refer to the [[devadasi]].Bayadère. Oxford English Dictionary. Retrieved February 1st, 2008 from Oxford English Dictionary.) The extant documents regarding the Shamakhi dancers, and dances, are very limited. In literature, Shamakhi dancers are referred to in [[Arthur Gobineau|Comte de Gobineau]]'s novel ''The dancing girl of Shamakha and other Asiatic tales''. ''The Dancer of Shamakha'' recounts the life of Armenian dancer [[Armen Ohanian]], her education as a dancer, her childhood in Russia, and her travels in Iran and Egypt. It was published in French as ''La Danseuse de Shamakha'' in 1918 and translated into English in 1923 by [[Rose Wilder]]. After moving to Europe, Ohanian danced traditional dances for audiences, gave lectures on poetry, and was an active member in intellectual and political circles. She eventually moved to Mexico. She is the author of some 15 publications including autobiographical volumes and books on culture and politics.Ohanian, Armen. ''La Danseuse de Shamakha''. Forward by Anatole France. Paris: Bernard Grasset, 1918 == See also == * [[Azerbaijani dances]] * [[Azerbaijani ballet]] ==References== {{reflist}} == Sources == *Joseph Arthur Comte de Gobineau, ''The dancing girl of Shamakha and other Asiatic tales'', authorized translation by [[Helen Morgenthau Fox]], 340 p. (Harcourt, Brace and Company, New York, 1926), OCLC 220571590; 368 p. (Kessinger Publishing, Montana, 2007), {{ISBN|1-4325-7982-7}} *Ohanian, Armen. ''La Danseuse de Shamakha''. Forward by Anatole France. Paris: Bernard Grasset, 1918 ==External links== * Some Azerbaijani dances:
— The traditional dance ''Land of Fire'', performed in [[Seoul]], 2007: [https://www.youtube.com/v/lxhaYUrapok&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (3 min 56 sec).
— The dance ''Magharas'', performed in Seoul, 2007: [https://www.youtube.com/v/p3uj3Kw8UvE&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (5 min 30 sec).
— ''Nelbeki'', a traditional Azarbaijani wedding dance, performed in Seoul, 2007: [https://www.youtube.com/v/QkMAkdadgeY&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (5 min 16 sec).
— The ''Yalli'' dance: [https://www.youtube.com/v/G_bh6FIjCmw&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (4 min 17 sec).
— A traditional group dance [https://www.youtube.com/v/Xi-vKeEdvuc&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (4 min 22 sec).
— A group dance: [https://www.youtube.com/v/_xQqZXDO8Nc&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (3 min 24 sec).
— A collection of group and solo dances: [https://www.youtube.com/v/RD06Sl1Qo1U&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (8 min 48 sec).
— Some solo dances: [https://www.youtube.com/v/zQJp6e6XaRk&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (3 min 30 sec); [https://www.youtube.com/v/hQhS81qLxzw&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (2 min 38 sec); [https://www.youtube.com/v/bMFpNXsSgD4&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (3 min 17 sec). * ''Sandirak'', a traditional Caucasian dance, Moscow, 2007: [https://www.youtube.com/v/trwcUq44SUU&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (8 min 03 sec). * A Caucasian dance: [https://www.youtube.com/v/lDVJodDyE94&hl=en&fs=1&rel=0&border=1] (4 min 24 sec). * {{Citation |publisher = Lulu |publication-place = London |author = Armen Ohanian |ol = 24549255M |title = The Dancer of Shamakha |publication-date = 2010 }} [[Category:Entertainment occupations]] [[Category:Theatrical occupations]] [[Category:Azerbaijani culture]] [[Category:Azerbaijani dancers]] [[Category:Azerbaijani dances]] [[Category:Iranian culture]] [[Category:Shamakhi District]] [[Category:19th-century dancers]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox media franchise |title = The Exorcist |image = Exorcist ver2.jpg |imagesize = |caption = ''[[The Exorcist (film)|The Exorcist]]'' theatrical release poster |creator = [[William Peter Blatty]] |owner = |origin =''[[The Exorcist (novel)|The Exorcist]]'' |books = |novels = ''The Exorcist''
''[[Legion (Blatty novel)|Legion]]'' |short_stories = |comics = |graphic_novels = |strips = |magazines = |films = ''[[The Exorcist (film)|The Exorcist]]''
''[[Exorcist II: The Heretic]]''
''[[The Exorcist III]]''
''The Exorcist (2000 Director's Cut)''
''[[Exorcist: The Beginning]]''
''[[Dominion: Prequel to the Exorcist]]'' |shorts = |tv = ''[[The Exorcist (TV series)]]'' |atv = |tv_specials = |tv_films = |dtv = |plays = |musicals = |games = |rpgs = |vgs = |radio = |soundtracks = |music = |toys = |attractions = |otherlabel1 = |otherdata1 = |otherlabel2 = |otherdata2 = |otherlabel3 = |otherdata3 = |website = |footnotes = }} '''''The Exorcist''''' is an American [[media franchise]] that originated with [[William Peter Blatty]]'s [[The Exorcist (novel)|1971 horror novel of the same name]] and most prominently featured in a [[The Exorcist (film)|1973 film adapted from the novel]], and [[The Exorcist (film series)|many subsequent prequels and sequels]]. All of these installments focus on fictional accounts of people [[Demonic possession|possessed]] by [[Pazuzu (The Exorcist)|Pazuzu]], the main antagonist of the series, and the efforts of religious authorities to counter this possession. ==Novels== ===''The Exorcist'' (1971)=== {{main|The Exorcist (novel)}} '''''The Exorcist''''' is a 1971 novel by American writer [[William Peter Blatty]]. The book details the [[demonic possession]] of twelve-year-old [[Regan MacNeil]], the daughter of a famous actress, and the two priests who attempt to [[exorcise]] the demon. It was published by [[Harper (publisher)|Harper & Row]]. The novel was inspired by a 1949 case of [[demonic possession]] and [[exorcism]] that Blatty heard about while he was a student in the class of 1950 at [[Georgetown University]].{{Cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=7h9huFdnsmcC&pg=PA132&dq=Robbie+Mannheim&cd=5#v=onepage&q=Robbie%20Mannheim&f=false|title= Dimension Desconocida|publisher= Ediciones Robinbook|quote= La inspiración del exorcista La historia de Robbie Mannheim es un caso típico de posesión, y es la que dio vida a la película ''El Exorcista''.|accessdate = 2010-04-04|isbn = 9788499170015|year = 2009}} As a result, the novel takes place in Washington D.C. near the campus of Georgetown University. In September 2011, the novel was reprinted by Harper Collins to celebrate its fortieth anniversary, with slight revisions made by Blatty as well as interior title artwork by [[Jeremy Caniglia]]. ===''Legion'' (1983)=== {{main|Legion (Blatty novel)}} ''[[Legion (Blatty novel)|Legion]]'' is the 1983 follow-up to the ''Exorcist'' novel. It was made into the movie ''[[The Exorcist III]]'' in 1990. Like ''The Exorcist'', it involves [[demonic possession]]. The book was the focus of a court case over its exclusion from [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''The New York Times'' Best Seller list]]. Blatty based aspects of the Gemini Killer on the real-life [[Zodiac Killer]],{{cite web |url=http://www.movietome.com/movie/282482/the-exorcist-iii/index.html |title=The Exorcist III Info, Trailers, and Reviews at MovieTome |publisher=Movietome.com |date= |accessdate=7 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090928072014/http://www.movietome.com/movie/282482/the-exorcist-iii/index.html |archivedate=28 September 2009 |df= }} who, in a January 1974 letter to the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', had praised the original ''[[The Exorcist (film)|Exorcist]]'' film as "the best satirical comedy that I have ever seen".{{cite news|title=Zodiac Killer : The Letters - 01-29-1974|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/slideshow/Zodiac-Killer-The-Letters-37941/photo-2467717.php|publisher=SFGate (''San Francisco Chronicle'')|accessdate=7 April 2013|date=2 December 2008}} ==Films== {{main|The Exorcist (film series)}} {|class="sortable wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ececec" |'''Film'''||'''Release date |- |''[[The Exorcist (film)|The Exorcist]]'' |December 26, 1973 |- |''[[Exorcist II: The Heretic]]'' |June 17, 1977 |- |''[[The Exorcist III]]'' |August 17, 1990 |- |''The Exorcist'' (director's cut) |September 22, 2000 |- |''[[Exorcist: The Beginning]]'' |August 20, 2004 |- |''[[Dominion: Prequel to the Exorcist]]'' |May 20, 2005 |- |} ===''The Exorcist'' (1973)=== {{main|The Exorcist (film)}} '''''The Exorcist''''' is a 1973 American [[Supernatural fiction|supernatural]] [[horror film]] directed by [[William Friedkin]], adapted by [[William Peter Blatty]] from his 1971 [[The Exorcist (novel)|novel of the same name]], and starring [[Ellen Burstyn]], [[Linda Blair]], [[Max von Sydow]], and [[Jason Miller (playwright)|Jason Miller]]. The film is part of [[The Exorcist (franchise)|''The Exorcist'' franchise]].The book, inspired by the 1949 [[exorcism]] of [[Exorcism of Roland Doe|Roland Doe]],{{Sfn|Fry|2008|p=130}}{{Sfn|Pons|2009|p=132}} deals with the [[demonic possession]] of a 12-year-old girl and her mother's attempts to win back her child through an exorcism conducted by two priests. The adaptation is relatively faithful to the book, which itself has been commercially successful (hitting the [[New York Times bestseller list|''New York Times'' bestseller list]]).{{cite news|first=Mike|last=Holtzclaw|accessdate=August 8, 2015|url=http://www.dailypress.com/entertainment/blog/dp-popcorn-the-exorcist-1024-story.html|title=The sound and fury of 'The Exorcist'|date=October 24, 2014|publisher=''[[Daily Press (Virginia)|Daily Press]]''}}{{cite web|accessdate=August 8, 2015|url=http://news.moviefone.com/2013/12/26/the-exorcist-facts/|title='The Exorcist': 25 Things You Didn't Know About the Terrifying Horror Classic|date=December 26, 2013|first=Gary|last=Susman|publisher=[[moviefone.com|news.moviefone.com]]}} ===''Exorcist II: The Heretic'' (1977)=== {{main|Exorcist II: The Heretic}} [[John Boorman]]'s ''[[Exorcist II: The Heretic]]'' was released in 1977, and revisited Regan four years after her initial ordeal. The plot dealt with an investigation into the legitimacy of Merrin's exorcism of Regan in the first film. In flashback sequences, we see Regan giving Merrin his fatal heart attack, as well as scenes from the exorcism of a young boy named Kokumo in Africa many years earlier. ===''The Exorcist III'' (1990)=== {{main|The Exorcist III}} ''[[The Exorcist III]]'' appeared in 1990, written and directed by Blatty himself from his own 1983 novel ''[[Legion (Blatty novel)|Legion]]''. Jumping past the events of ''Exorcist II'', this book and film presented a continuation of Karras' story. Following the precedent set in ''[[The Ninth Configuration]],'' Blatty turned a supporting character from the first film—in this case, Kinderman—into the chief protagonist. Though the characters of Karras and Kinderman were acquainted during the murder investigation in ''The Exorcist'' and Kinderman expressed fondness for Karras, in ''Exorcist III'' Blatty has Kinderman remembering Karras as his "best friend". [[Jason Miller (playwright)|Jason Miller]] reprised his Academy Award-nominated role in ''The Exorcist'' for this film. ===''Exorcist: The Beginning'' (2004)=== {{main|Exorcist: The Beginning}} Because of the studio's dissatisfaction with Schrader's version of the prequel (see "Dominion: Prequel to the Exorcist"), [[Renny Harlin]] was then hired as director to retool the movie. Harlin reused some of Schrader's footage but shot mostly new material to create a more conventional horror film. Harlin's new version ''[[Exorcist: The Beginning]]'' was released, but was not well received. ===''Dominion: Prequel to the Exorcist'' (2005)=== {{main|Dominion: Prequel to the Exorcist}} A prequel film attracted attention and controversy even before its release in 2004; it went through a number of directorial and script changes, such that two versions were ultimately released. [[John Frankenheimer]] was originally hired as director for the project, but withdrew before filming started due to health concerns. He died a month later. [[Paul Schrader]] replaced him. Upon completion the studio rejected Schrader's version as being too slow, and hired another director to retool the movie. Nine months after the release of the retooled movie (see "Exorcist: The Beginning") Schrader's original version, retitled ''[[Dominion: Prequel to the Exorcist]]'', was given a small theatrical release. ===Box office=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:99%;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| '''Film''' ! rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| '''Release date''' ! colspan="3" style="text-align:center;"| '''Box office revenue''' ! colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" text="wrap"| '''Box office ranking''' ! rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| '''Budget''' ! rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| '''Reference''' |- ! style="text-align:center;"| '''United States''' ! style="text-align:center;"| '''Foreign''' ! style="text-align:center;"| '''Worldwide''' ! web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=exorcist.htm|title=The Exorcist (1973)|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1973/0XRCS.php|publisher=The Numbers|title=Movie The Exorcist - Box Office Data|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mr9Aw3Qj?url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1973/0XRCS.php|archivedate=2010-01-17|deadurl=no|df=}} |- |$78,000,586 | style="text-align:center;"| #1,324 | style="background:lightgrey;"| | style="text-align:center;"|$80,000,000 | style="text-align:center;"|{{cite |$331,592,458 |$329,886,082(A) |$661,478,540(A) | | | style="text-align:center;"|$103,000,000(A) |- | colspan="9" | '''List indicator(s)''' * A dark grey cell indicates the information is not available for the film. * (L) indicates the film had a limited release. * (A) indicates an estimated figure based on available numbers. |} ===Related films=== ====''The Ninth Configuration'' (1980)==== {{main|The Ninth Configuration}} Blatty directed ''[[The Ninth Configuration]]'', a post-[[Vietnam War]] drama set in a mental institution. Released in 1980, it was based on Blatty's novel of the same name. Though it contrasts sharply with the tone of ''The Exorcist,'' Blatty regards ''Configuration'' as its true sequel.{{cite web|url=http://www.electricsheepmagazine.co.uk/features/2011/02/25/light-in-the-darkness-william-peter-blattys-faith-trilogy/|work=Electric Sheep Magazine|title=Light in the Darkness: William Peter Blatty’s Faith Trilogy|date=February 25, 2011|author=Fitch, Alex|accessdate=May 6, 2016}} The lead character is the astronaut from Chris' party, Lt. Cutshaw. ====''Possessed'' (2000)==== {{main|Possessed (2000 film)}} A made-for-television film, ''[[Possessed (2000 film)|Possessed]]'' (based on the book of the same name by [[Thomas B. Allen (author)|Thomas B. Allen]]), was broadcast on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] on October 22, 2000, directed by [[Steven E. de Souza]] and written by de Souza and Michael Lazarou. The film claimed to follow the true accounts that inspired Blatty to write ''The Exorcist'' and starred [[Timothy Dalton]], [[Henry Czerny]], and [[Christopher Plummer]]. ==Television series== {{main|The Exorcist (TV series)}} On January 22, 2016, [[20th Century Fox Television]] announced they were developing a [[The Exorcist (TV series)|television series]] of ''The Exorcist''.{{cite web|title=‘The Exorcist’ Pilot Ordered at Fox with Modern Twist|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/the-exorcist-tv-series-pilot-fox-1201686653/|last=Prudom|first=Laura|website=Variety.com|accessdate=February 2, 2016}} On February 2, 2016, [[Rupert Wyatt]] was hired to direct the pilot episode.{{cite web|title=Rupert Wyatt To Resurrect A Horror Icon By Helming TV Pilot Of The Exorcist|url=http://wegotthiscovered.com/tv/rupert-wyatt-to-resurrect-a-horror-icon-by-helming-tv-pilot-of-the-exorcist/|last= Briers|first= Michael|website=wegotthiscovered.com|accessdate=February 2, 2016}} On March 2, 2016, [[Alfonso Herrera]] and [[Ben Daniels]] were cast as Father Tomas Ortega and Father Marcus Lang.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/exorcist-alfonso-herrera-ben-daniels-cast-fox-pilot-remake-1201713164/|title=‘Exorcist’: Alfonso Herrera & Ben Daniels To Star In Fox Drama Pilot|publisher=Deadline|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=March 2, 2016}} [[Geena Davis]] was cast as Angela Rance in the pilot.{{cite web|last1=Wagmeister|first1=Elizabeth|title=Geena Davis Cast in Fox’s ‘Exorcist’ Reboot Pilot|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/geena-davis-the-exorcist-fox-pilot-1201724304/|website=Variety.com|accessdate=March 7, 2016}} The pilot filmed in Chicago in early 2016, and on May 10 the series was greenlit for a first season.{{cite web|last1=Elber|first1=Lynn|title=Fox orders series based on 'Lethal Weapon,' 'Exorcist'|url=http://www.denverpost.com/ci_29875108/fox-orders-series-based-lethal-weapon-exorcist/|website=denverpost.com|accessdate=May 12, 2016}} ==Theatre== ===''The Exorcist'' (2012)=== {{main|The Exorcist (play)}} In February 2008, American playwright [[John Pielmeier]] expressed an interest in adapting [[William Peter Blatty]]'s [[The Exorcist (novel)|novel of the same name]] into a play and soon met with Blatty. He then began working on a script for the play, in which the first draft was completed in ten days.{{Cite web|url=http://johnpielmeier.com/theater/plays/the-exorcist/|title=The Exorcist {{!}} John Pielmeier|website=johnpielmeier.com|access-date=2016-09-30}} [[The Exorcist (play)|''The Exorcist'']] first premiered at the [[Geffen Playhouse]], Los Angeles in 2012. ==Video Game== ===''The Exorcist: Legion VR'' (2017)=== A horror VR video game, called 'The Exorcist: Legion VR', was published on [[Steam_(software)|Steam]], Oculus and PlayStation in 2018 and was based on the events of The Exorcist III. http://www.exorcistlegion.com/http://store.steampowered.com/app/708580/The_Exorcist_Legion_VR/https://exorcistvr.com/Oculushttps://exorcistvr.com/PSVR ==Unmade sequels and remakes== In November 2009, it was announced that Blatty planned to direct a [[mini-series]] of ''The Exorcist''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18103|title='The Exorcist' Miniseries Reteams Original Writer/Director?}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cemeterydance.com/ |title=Cemetery Dance #62: The William Peter Blatty special issue shipping now! |publisher=Cemeterydance.com |date= |accessdate=August 2, 2012}} In September 2015, [[Morgan Creek Productions]] announced it was selling its library of films, while retaining remake and sequel rights to key properties, including ''The Exorcist''. Rumors began circulating that the original film would be remade, which was denied by Morgan Creek.{{cite web|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3363403/morgan-creek-confirms-they-will-not-remake-the-exorcist/|work=Bloody-Disgusting|title=Morgan Creek Confirms They Will NOT Remake ‘The Exorcist’|author=Barkan, Jonathan|date=September 28, 2015|accessdate=May 6, 2016}} ==Parodies and pastiches== The success of ''The Exorcist'' inspired a string of possession-related films worldwide. The first was ''[[Beyond the Door (1974 film)|Beyond the Door]]'', a 1974 Italian film with [[Juliet Mills]] as a woman possessed by the devil. It appeared in the U.S. one year later. Also in 1974, a Turkish film, ''[[Şeytan]]'' (Turkish for ''Satan''; the original film was also shown with the same name), is an almost scene-for-scene [[remake]] of the original. The same year in Germany, the exorcism-themed film ''Magdalena, vom Teufel besessen'' was released. In 1975, Britain released ''[[The Devil Within Her]]'' (also called ''[[I Don't Want to Be Born]]'') with [[Joan Collins]] as an exotic dancer who gives birth to a demon-possessed child. In 1987, Warner Brothers released an animated short starring Daffy Duck, entitled "Duxorcist" which was a parody of "Exorcist", where a group of spirits possess a female duck, and Daffy does succeed in getting them out of the female figure. Similarly, a [[blaxploitation]] film was released in 1974 titled ''[[Abby (film)|Abby]]''. While the films ''Şeytan'' and ''Magdalena, vom Teufel besessen'' were protected from prosecution by the laws of their countries of origin, ''Abby''{{'}}s producers (filming in Louisiana) were sued by Warner. The film was pulled from theaters, but not before making $4 million at the box office. A parody, ''[[Repossessed]]'', was released the same year as ''The Exorcist III'', with Blair lampooning the role she had played in the original. Another parody, was made in Italy by actor and comedian [[Ciccio Ingrassia]] in 1977, called [[L'esorciccio]]. The prologue for ''[[Scary Movie 2]]'' was a short parody of several scenes from the original. Mexican comics "Los Polivoces", (The Multivoices), made a copy-parody, called "El Exorcista". Eduardo Manzano incarned{{Elucidate|date=June 2017}} the "possession", hard make-up was used. Flying clothes were used as "phantoms" and rotoscophy techniques make his bed fly. ===Other references=== A 1995 episode of ''[[The Simpsons]]'' (titled "[[Home Sweet Homediddly-Dum-Doodily]]") features [[Bart Simpson|Bart]], [[Lisa Simpson|Lisa]] and Maggie getting put under the care of the Flanders family. After Lisa reveals that neither she, Bart nor Maggie is [[baptism|baptized]], [[Ned Flanders|Ned]] decides to baptize them. On the way to the baptism, Maggie turns her head around like Linda Blair in ''The Exorcist''. It was also parodied in [[Treehouse of Horror I]], [[Treehouse of Horror XVI]] and [[Treehouse of Horror XXVIII]]. It was also parodied in "[[Fland Canyon]]". A meta-reference to the film was made in an episode of ''[[Supernatural (U.S. TV series)|Supernatural]]'' titled "The Usual Suspects". On the show, demons possessing humans is a common plot element; demons in the series are human souls corrupted by their time in Hell, lacking physical bodies of their own to interact with Earth. Linda Blair appeared in "The Usual Suspects" as a police detective, with protagonist [[Dean Winchester]] finding her character familiar and expressing a strange desire for pea soup at the episode's conclusion. In ''Angel: Earthly Possessions'', a spin-off comic story based on the TV series ''[[Angel (1999 TV series)|Angel]]'', protagonist [[Angel (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Angel]] finds himself dealing with a priest who performs exorcisms, but comes to realize that the priest is summoning the demons for him to exorcise in the first place. He also makes a note of ''The Exorcist'' film, noting that the vision it created of possession actually made things easier for possession demons by making it harder for humans to know what to expect from a possession. In the animated [[Horror-comedy]] show ''[[Courage the Cowardly Dog]]'', the episode "[[List of Courage the Cowardly Dog episodes|The Demon In The Mattress]]" is a direct spoof of the film, using several plot elements that was lifted straight from ''The Exorcist''. In the episode, Muriel orders a comfy new mattress, not paying attention to the grotesque deliveryman nor the sinister [[Horse-drawn carriage]] that delivered it. Unaware of the demon in the mattress, she is later possessed by it when while she sleeps. In the paranormal TV show ''[[Ghost Adventures]]'' visited the Exorcist House for their 100th episode of the series. In the episode, Zak, Nick, and Aaron visit the house to see that an exorcism occurred there in 1949. The episode has been announced as one of the scariest lockdown since Bobby Mackeys. The film was parodied in [[The Boondocks (TV series)|''The Boondocks'']] episode "Stinkmeaner Strikes Back" ([[The Boondocks (season 2)|season 2, episode 4]]). The 2013 disaster comedy film ''[[This Is the End]]'' referenced the exorcism when [[Jonah Hill]] is possessed by a demon and [[Jay Baruchel]] performs an exorcism on by repeating lines from the movie. In 2014, British author [[Saurav Dutt]] released a book entitled "''Pazuzu Unbound''", which is a book set in contemporary times dealing with the demon Pazuzu but which does not deal with the original characters in the film and novel on which the book is inspired. ==Characters== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:95%" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:15%;"| Character ! colspan="5" style="text-align:center;"| Film ! colspan="1" style="text-align:center;"| Television series |- ! style="text-align:center; width:14.5%;"| ''[[The Exorcist (film)|The Exorcist]]'' (1973) ! style="text-align:center; width:14.5%;"| ''[[Exorcist II: The Heretic]]'' (1977) ! style="text-align:center; width:14.5%;"| ''[[The Exorcist III]]'' (1990) ! style="text-align:center; width:14.5%;"| ''[[Exorcist: The Beginning]]'' (2004) ! style="text-align:center; width:14.5%;"| ''[[Dominion: Prequel to the Exorcist]]'' (2005) ! style="text-align:center; width:14.5%;"| ''[[The Exorcist (TV series)|The Exorcist]]'' (2016-2017) |- ! page.title: The World at the End of Time

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = The World at the End of Time | title_orig = | translator = | image = TheWorldAtTheEndOfTime(1stEd).jpg | caption = Cover of first edition (hardcover) | author = [[Frederik Pohl]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | publisher = [[Del Rey Books]] | release_date = June 1, 1990 | media_type = Print (hardback & paperback) | pages = 393 | isbn = 0-345-33976-2 | dewey= 813/.54 20 | congress= PS3566.O36 W67 1990 | oclc= 20798288 }} '''''World at the End of Time''''' is a 1990 [[hard science fiction]] novel by [[United States|American]] writer [[Frederik Pohl]]. It tells the parallel stories of a human and a plasma-based intelligence who manage to survive to the time near the [[heat death of the universe]]. The book is thus a combined work in speculative [[cosmology]] and [[space colonization]].
==Plot summary==
''World at the End of Time'' follows the story of a young Earth-born human, Viktor Sorricaine, on a colony expedition to a distant star system. The colonists are frozen for the long trip between stars. Unknown to both the humans of Earth and the colonists, the stars around them are home to immensely long-lived (effectively immortal) [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] creatures—with no knowledge of, or interest in, the activities of insignificant matter creatures.
Wan-To, one of the oldest and most powerful plasma creatures, is engaged in a war. After creating modified copies of himself, or "children", for company, Wan-To finds himself in a deadly game of chess with them. The "board" is the entire galaxy and the weapons are the stars themselves. Each star may be home to an enemy "child"; using a variety of exotic particles, Wan-To is able to cause a targeted star to flare and kill any enemy that may be living within it.
Into the middle of this battlefield, the three colony ships (''Ark'', ''New Mayflower'' and ''Argosy'') unwittingly head for their new home. Upon arriving, the colony begins to establish itself ... only to discover that their entire local group of stars appears to be undergoing a bizarre acceleration, and are dimming. After a disastrous disease outbreak and [[terraforming]] failures, the desperate colonists eventually decide to investigate the strange radiation emissions from a small world within their solar system.
Upon arriving in orbit, their ship is badly damaged and Viktor is forced into the onboard freezer systems. They are eventually rescued and unfrozen four hundred of the colony's years later, to find the colony in an even more desperate situation. The star around which the colony's world orbits has dimmed considerably (due to the energy being siphoned off to accelerate it) and they are now travelling so fast that, due to relativistic effects, the universe around them has shrunk to a bright dot. The colony has become factionalized and heavily religious, with scientific investigation discouraged.
Viktor is eventually frozen again for attempting to investigate why they have been accelerating. He wakes four thousand of the colony's years later, to find the far descendants of the colony have rebuilt their society into habitats closely orbiting the dim star (a [[brown dwarf]]) and created a high-technology civilization dedicated to pleasure and comfort. He makes his way, eventually, to the former colony to find only a few fellow-colonists unfrozen and attempting to rebuild it. His unique status as someone who was born on "old Earth" brings publicity to their efforts and the rebuilding forges ahead.
During the four thousand years of Viktor's frozen sleep, the star system has been slowed again. After the vast amount of time that has passed, all that remains of the once young universe are dead stars and black holes, with Wan-To desperately surviving on the energy provided by [[proton decay]]. Wan-To receives a [[tachyon]] transmission from his long-forgotten systems and makes preparations to move into these last remaining stars — believing that the small matter creatures inhabiting the system are irrelevant and can be destroyed should they become an irritation.
{{Frederik Pohl}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:World At The End Of Time}} [[Category:1990 American novels]] [[Category:American science fiction novels]] [[Category:Novels by Frederik Pohl]] [[Category:End of the universe in fiction]] [[Category:Hard science fiction]] [[Category:Del Rey books]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox video game | title = Tom Clancy's The Division | image = The Division box.jpg | developer = [[Massive Entertainment]]{{efn|Additional work by [[Ubisoft Reflections]], [[Red Storm Entertainment]] [[Ubisoft Annecy]] and [[Ubisoft Leamington]]}} | publisher = [[Ubisoft]] | series = ''[[Tom Clancy's]]'' | engine = [[Snowdrop (game engine)|Snowdrop]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]]
[[PlayStation 4]]
[[Xbox One]] | released = 8 March 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-division-delayed-now-slated-for-early-2016-rel/1100-6427277/|title=The Division Delayed, Now Slated for Early 2016 Release|first=Chris|last=Pereira |date=12 May 2015|accessdate=12 May 2015|work=[[GameSpot]]}} | genre = [[Action role-playing game|Action role-playing]], [[Survival game|survival]] | modes = [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] | director = Magnus Jansén
Julian Gerigh | producer = Petter Sydow | designer = Matthias Karlson | programmer = | artist = | writer = | composer = Ola Strandh{{cite web|last=Greening|first=Chris|title=The Division composed by Ubisoft Massive in-house musician|url=http://www.vgmonline.net/the-division-composed-by-ubisoft-massive-in-house-musician/|publisher=Game Music Online|accessdate=11 June 2014}} }} '''''Tom Clancy's The Division''''' is an [[Action role-playing game|action role-playing]] [[video game]] developed by [[Massive Entertainment]] and published by [[Ubisoft]], with assistance from [[Red Storm Entertainment]] and Ubisoft Annecy, for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]]. It was announced during Ubisoft's [[E3 2013]] press conference, and was released worldwide on 8 March 2016. It is set in a near future [[New York City]] in the aftermath of a [[smallpox]] [[pandemic]]; the player, who is a Special Agent of the eponymous Strategic Homeland Division, commonly referred to simply as "Division", is tasked with helping the group rebuild its operations in [[Manhattan]], investigate the nature of the outbreak, and combating criminal activity in its wake. ''The Division'' is structured with elements of [[Role-playing video game|role-playing games]], as well as cooperative and [[player versus player]] online multiplayer. The game received generally positive reviews, and was a commercial success, with Ubisoft stating that the game broke the company's record for highest number of first-day sales. Furthermore, one week after the game's release, Ubisoft stated that ''The Division'' was the company's best-selling game, and the industry's biggest first-week launch for a new game franchise, which generated an estimated amount of $330 million globally. A sequel, ''[[Tom Clancy's The Division 2]]'', is scheduled to be released in March 2019. == Gameplay == [[File:Tom Clancy's The Division gameplay screenshot.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Players may take cover behind objects during firefights to avoid taking damage from enemies, and to give them a [[Positional advantage|tactical advantage]] when attacking.]] ''Tom Clancy's The Division'' is an [[Action role-playing game|action role-playing]] game set in an [[open world]] mid-crisis [[Manhattan]] with destructible environments that can be freely explored by the players. The player's mission is to restore order by investigating the source of a virus. The player character can carry three weapons, and explosives like sticky bombs and seeker mines to fight against enemies.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/the-division-preview-playing-pvp-in-the-lawless-dark-zone/|title=The Division preview: playing PvP in the lawless Dark Zone|first=Samuel|last=Roberts|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=15 June 2015|accessdate=26 November 2015}} Players may take cover behind objects during fire-fights to avoid taking damage from enemies, and to give them a tactical advantage when attacking. The game is played from a [[Virtual camera system#Third-person view|third-person perspective]], meaning the character model is visible.{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/6/23/8827287/the-division-hands-on-e3-xbox-one-ps4-preview|title=The Division has promise — if you can keep from shooting the wrong people|first=Arthur|last=Gies|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=23 June 2015|accessdate=26 November 2015}} As players progress, they earn [[Experience (gaming)|experience points]] (commonly known as XP) and currency. They can use this currency to buy weapons and gear, and use the points to learn new talents and skills. The player's gear is categorized into seven levels: worn, standard, specialized, superior, high-end, gear set items or the rarer exotic items, each with a specific color code. Gear can be either bought, or found as in-game loot, or crafted from gathered materials. The storyline missions involve objectives that are relevant to their respective wing of the Base of Operations, which serves as the player's home base. At the player's home base there are three wings which are the Medical, Security and Tech wing. Playing missions for a wing grants the player points for that wing which the player can spend to gain access to new talents, perks and facilities in the Base of Operations. The player will receive intel videos from each head of the wing at certain progression points, which the player can watch. The intel received is specific to its wing, with the Medical wing giving virus reports on the outbreak, the Security wing giving insight into each in-game enemy faction and the tech wing providing camera footage.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/division-character-progression-mmo/?tag=grsocial-20|title=The Division's character progression sure sounds like an MMO|first=Connor|last=Sheridan|work=[[GamesRadar]]|date=26 November 2015|accessdate=26 November 2015}} The game features a dynamic, time-based weather system which may bring benefits or disadvantages to players. For instance, storms can hinder player's visibility and make aiming difficult. The game also features a day-night cycle which can change the behaviour of enemies in the game.{{cite web|url=https://www.vg247.com/2015/10/23/the-division-pc-ps4-xbox-one/|title=The Division – more on how dynamic weather and lighting can affect gameplay|first=Stephany |last=Nunneley|work=[[VG247]]|date=23 October 2015|accessdate=26 November 2015}} The Dark Zone is the player-versus-player competitive multiplayer mode featured in ''The Division'', where a lot of high-end weapons are left behind when the military retreats in the game. It is separated from the main campaign and has its own progression system. Higher quality items can be found within the Dark Zone, but are considered "contaminated"; contaminated loot can be stolen by other players, and must be flown out via helicopter in order for them to be available to the player after they leave the Dark Zone.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-division-s-pvp-dark-zones-detailed/1100-6425586/|title=The Division's PvP "Dark Zones" Detailed|first=Eddie|last=Makuch|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=27 February 2015|accessdate=26 November 2015}} Players can be accompanied by several co-operative partners and other neutral, player-controlled agents. These people, however, can turn against the player at any moment, going rogue. Players' [[Level (role-playing games)|level]] and ranking may drop if they die too often in the zone. ==Plot== On [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]] 2015, a [[smallpox]] [[pandemic]], transmitted by a virus planted on [[banknotes]], sweeps through [[New York City]]. The disease, known as "Green Poison" or "The Dollar Flu", causes widespread chaos, and [[Manhattan]] is placed under quarantine. The [[Federal government of the United States|U.S. Government]] activates sleeper agents in the population who operate for the Strategic Homeland Division, or simply "The Division", to assist emergency responders, now called the Joint Task Force (JTF), in restoring order. In [[Brooklyn]], the [[protagonist]], a Division agent, assists the JTF before planning to depart for the Quarantine zone with fellow agent Faye Lau. However, the [[VTOL]] meant to take them there is destroyed in an explosion, killing the Division Commander along with most of the second wave and severely wounding Faye Lau. Arriving in a JTF-commandeered news helicopter instead, the Division agents reclaim the [[James A. Farley Post Office Building]] as their base of operations. From there, the agents undertake assignments to rescue important personnel, help in restoring the base of operations to full working capacity and combat criminal groups, such as the Rioters, common street thugs in New York who generally want to take advantage of the quarantine, the Rikers, escapees from [[Rikers Island]], and the Cleaners, insane [[New York City Department of Sanitation|New York Sanitation]] workers who wield flamethrowers and believe everyone is infected. In the course of the game, the agent helps rescue important personnel like Dr. Jessica Kandel, Captain Roy Benitez and Paul Rhodes. These personnel head the Medical, Security and Tech wings of the base of operations respectively. Agents also recover a sample of Green Poison. Studying the sample reveals the virus was manufactured and then modified heavily by a controversial biologist named Dr. Gordon Amherst. Eventually, the agents find footage of Division agent Aaron Keener going rogue and killing other agents, having gone insane after witnessing the chaos and destruction caused during the breakdown of order following the initial outbreak. It is also discovered Keener and the rest of the first wave of agents who went rogue along with him are assisting the "Last Man Battalion" (LMB), an equally rogue [[private military company]] that was abandoned by the government during the evacuation, and are now hostile to it. Working together, these two groups destroyed the VTOL and killed the Commander to weaken Division operations in New York. Intercepting a signal from the Russian consulate, the agents attempt to rescue Vitaly Tchernenko, a Russian virologist who claims to have information on the Green Poison. However, he is kidnapped by Keener and the LMB before the Division can reach him. After helping the JTF secure supplies and weapons, the JTF and Division agents launch an attack on the LMB's base, the evacuated [[Headquarters of the United Nations|United Nations headquarters]]. The agent finds footage of Keener and his fellow rogue agents abandoning the LMB, with Tchernenko as their prisoner. The leader of the LMB, Charles Bliss, initially escapes in a helicopter, but then returns to make a final stand alongside his men. In the end, the agent destroys the vehicle, killing Bliss. Lau informs the agent that most threats are destroyed or weakened, however the LMB was split into factions. New York is approaching stability, but an unknown signal leads the agent to a secluded laboratory. There, they find Dr. Amherst's remains, having discovered that he has died from exposure to his own virus. They also find a message from Keener, showing he has the technology to manufacture a new strain of Green Poison and intends to do so, and mysteriously tells the agent to explore the center of Manhattan, called the “Dark Zone.” The agent is informed that the information in the lab will further the development of a vaccine and is shown a recovered message from Amherst. In the message, Amherst reveals he engineered Green Poison as part of his [[eco-terrorist]] plan to decimate the human race and preserve the planet. If the player follows Keener's instructions, they will discover a message from Keener claiming that he plans to continue with Amherst's plot, as he has come to worship the virus as the judge of all humanity and plans to reverse engineer and improve it; he then offers the player a position beside him based on their actions in the Dark Zone. ==Development== ''Tom Clancy's The Division'' was originally being developed as an [[History of video game consoles (eighth generation)|eighth generation consoles]] exclusive.{{cite web |url=http://tomclancy-thedivision.ubi.com/game/en-US/game_info/index.aspx |title=The Division homepage |publisher=[[Ubisoft]] |accessdate=20 August 2013}} Shortly after the game's unveiling, Ubisoft stated that other platforms were not ruled out.{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/TheDivisionGame/status/344682013430804481 |title=Tweet about other platforms |publisher=[[Twitter]] |accessdate=12 June 2013}} Ubisoft asked PC gamers to show interest in the game by signing petitions, and then they would decide. The new [[intellectual property]] and tech has been in development for several years although development on the actual game began in early 2013.{{cite web |last=Papadopoulos |first=John |date=14 June 2014 |url=http://www.dsogaming.com/news/ubisoft-asks-pc-gamers-to-show-interest-about-the-division-petition-almost-hits-its-initial-goal/ |title=Ubisoft asks PC gamers to show interest about The Division, petition almost hits its initial goal |publisher=DSOGaming|accessdate=14 June 2014}}{{cite web |last=Savage |first=Phil |date=17 June 2013 |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/2013/06/17/the-division-ubisoft-encourages-players-to-sign-pc-petition-over-50000-do/ |title=The Division: Ubisoft encourages players to sign PC petition – over 50,000 do |publisher=[[PC Gamer]]|accessdate=13 May 2014}} During [[E3 2013]], the game was officially announced,{{cite web |last=Goldfarb |first=Andrew |date=10 June 2013 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/06/10/e3-2013-open-world-tom-clancy-rpg-the-division-announced |title=E3 2013: Open World Tom Clancy RPG The Division Announced |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=20 August 2013}}{{cite web |last=LeJacq |first=Yannick |date=10 June 2013 |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/technology/ubisoft-unveils-tom-clancy-game-division-6C10272293 |title=Ubisoft unveils Tom Clancy game 'The Division' |publisher=[[NBC News]] |accessdate=10 June 2013}} with a trailer explaining the results of [[Operation Dark Winter]] and the purpose of [[National Security and Homeland Security Presidential Directive|Directive 51]]. During the Expo, Ubisoft announced a companion app that allows players to play the game on tablets. Players are able to join in the game as a drone to offer tactical support for players playing on PC and consoles.{{cite web |date=10 June 2013 |url=http://www.imore.com/tom-clancys-division-let-mobile-players-get-post-apocalyptic-console-action|title=Tom Clancy's The Division to let mobile players get in on post-apocalyptic console action |publisher=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |accessdate=20 August 2013}} On 20 August 2013, Ubisoft announced that the game would be released for PC on Microsoft Windows as a result of the "vocal and passionate PC community."{{cite web |last=Pitcher |first=Jenna |date=20 August 2013 |url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/8/20/4639462/the-division-confirmed-for-windows-pc |title=The Division confirmed for Windows PC |publisher=iMore|accessdate=20 August 2013}} On 7 February 2014, Ubisoft announced that [[Ubisoft Reflections]] was co-developing the game and was responsible for developing the map-design, character-design and the online components of the game.{{cite web |last=Sarkar |first=Samit |date=7 February 2014 |url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/2/7/5390010/the-division-co-developed-ubisoft-reflections-massive |title=The Division being co-developed by Ubisoft Reflections and Massive |publisher=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |accessdate=7 February 2014}} [[Red Storm Entertainment]], a subsidiary of Ubisoft that was co-founded by [[Tom Clancy]], was also working on the weapon-design of the game.{{cite web |last=Scammell |first=David |date=9 April 2014 |url=http://www.videogamer.com/ps4/tom_clancys_the_division/news/red_storm_teams_up_with_ubisoft_massive_on_the_division.html |title=Red Storm teams up with Ubisoft Massive on The Division |publisher=VideoGamer.com |accessdate=13 May 2014}} [[Ubisoft Annecy]] was also announced to be one of the co-developers of the game on 8 May 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/5/8/8576145/tom-clancys-the-division-ubisoft-annency-multiplayer|title=Ubisoft brings in another studio to help make Tom Clancy's The Division|first=Michael|last=McWhertor|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=8 May 2015|accessdate=9 May 2015}} On 15 May 2014, it was announced that ''The Division'' would be delayed until 2015, according to an anonymous source inside [[Massive Entertainment]] studio. ''The Division'' uses Ubisoft's new proprietary engine known as Snowdrop, which is made for PC, PlayStation 4 and Xbox One.{{cite web |last=Crecente |first=Brian |date=19 May 2014 |url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/3/19/5524924/the-division-video-snowdrop-game-engine |title=Here's The Division's amazing game engine in action |publisher=[[Polygon]] |accessdate=26 June 2015}} On 9 June 2014, ''The Division'' was showcased at [[E3 2014]] with an anticipated release for late 2015.{{cite web |last=Karmali |first=Luke |date=15 May 2014 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/01/07/the-division-may-be-delayed-to-2015 |title=The Division may be Delayed to 2015 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=15 May 2014}} In February 2016, Ubisoft announced that [[downloadable content]] for ''The Division'' would be timed exclusives for Xbox One.{{cite web|title=The Division's DLC will launch as timed Xbox One exclusive|url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/2/17/11033958/the-divisions-dlc-will-launch-as-timed-xbox-one-exclusive|website=Polygon|accessdate=17 February 2016}} During [[E3 2015]], the game's final release date and a [[player versus player]] area known as the Dark Zone were revealed.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/forging-fragile-alliances-at-e3-2015-in-the-divisi/1100-6428063/|title=Forging Fragile Alliances At E3 2015 In The Division's Dark Zones|first=Daniel|last=Hindes |work=[[GameSpot]]|date=16 June 2015|accessdate=16 June 2015}} Its companion app was cancelled, as the company considered that the addition of drones will bring unfairness to the competitive multiplayer mode of the game.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/division-subtracts-its-cool-looking-companion-app-drone-experience/|title=The Division subtracts its cool-looking companion app 'drone experience'|first=Connor |last=Sheridan|work=[[GamesRadar]]|date=15 June 2015|accessdate=16 June 2015}} Unlike the previous E3 demo, Long Island, and Staten Island do not appear in the game at launch, while Brooklyn only appears in the opening hours of the game as the tutorial area. The beta was set to be released for the Xbox One in December 2015 and for Windows and PlayStation 4 in 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/06/15/e3-2015-the-division-beta-begins-in-this-year|title=E3 2015: The Division Beta Begins In This Year|first=Daniel|last=Krupa|work=[[IGN]]|date=15 June 2015|accessdate=16 June 2015}} On 7 December 2015, Ubisoft announced that ''The Division''{{'}}s beta would be moved to "early 2016" and that an Xbox One exclusive alpha would begin on 9 December 2015. On 26 January 2016, it was confirmed that the closed Beta would begin on 28 January 2016 for [[Xbox One]] and 29 January 2016 for [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Microsoft Windows]],{{cite web |last=Sheridan|first=Connor|date=26 January 2016 |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/division-beta-start-time/ |title=Here's exactly when you can start playing The Division beta |work=[[GamesRadar]] |accessdate=26 January 2016}} and end, for all platforms, on 1 February 2016. On 31 January 2016, Ubisoft announced that they had extended the beta, and that it would end on 2 February 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/1/31/10880236/the-divisions-closed-beta-is-extended-one-day |title=The Division's closed beta is extended one day |last=Good |first=Owen S. |work=Polygon |date= 31 January 2016 |accessdate=9 February 2016}} On 9 February 2016, Ubisoft announced that ''The Division''{{'}}s open beta would begin for Xbox One on 18 February 2016, and for PC and PlayStation 4 on 19 February 2016, and would end for all platforms on 22 February 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.vg247.com/2016/02/09/the-division-open-beta-kicks-off-feb-18/ |title=The Division open beta kicks off February 18th, 2016 for Xbox One, February 19th, 2016 for PlayStation 4 and PC |last=Nunneley |first=Stephany |publisher=VG247 |date=9 February 2016 |accessdate=9 February 2016}} Over 6.4 million players, across all platforms, participated in the open beta. On 27 February 2016, Ubisoft confirmed that there would be no microtransactions at launch. ''The Division'' was released on 8 March 2016, two years after its initially planned release.{{cite web |last=Villegas|first=Jackie|date=23 January 2016 |url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/tom-clancys-the-division-release-date-details-new-video-game-is-compelling-and-realer-than-real-creative-director-says-155390/ |title='Tom Clancy's The Division' Release Date, Details: New Video Game Is 'Compelling' And 'Realer-Than-Real,' Creative Director Says |publisher=[[Christian Post]] |accessdate=26 January 2016}} There was a promotional short film released on Amazon prime titled ''The Division: Agent Origins''{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5354588 |title=IMDB Agent Origins.}} ===Post-release content=== The game is supported by additional content, such as daily and weekly missions, Dark Zone missions and free updates, after the game's launch. The April update, ''Incursions'' introduces new gadgets, a new area called Falcon Lost and updated AI to the game,.{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/gaming/656949/The-Division-Incursions-update-Ubisoft-Twitch-Dark-Zone-Xbox-One-PS4|title=The Division Incursions UPDATE: Falcon Lost underground lair and Dark Zone missions reveal|first=Gary|last=Jones|work=[[Express.co.uk]]|date=April 1, 2016|accessdate=April 6, 2016}} The May update, named ''Conflict'', adds Dark Zone Extraction Hijacking and the new Incursion - Clear Sky, which was released. The game was announced to be supported by 3 paid expansions. In June, ''Underground'', which includes missions set in tunnels and subways, was released. It was reported that it would be followed by ''Survival'', which adds the Survival game mode. ''Last Stand'' was set to be released in the last quarter of the year.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/03/03/the-division-dlc-detailed-release-windows-announced|title=The Division DLC Release Windows Announced|first=Michael|last=Passalacqua|work=[[IGN]]|date=March 3, 2016|accessdate=April 6, 2016}} ''Survival'' and ''Last Stand'' were delayed to late 2016 and early 2017 respectively, so that Ubisoft can focus its effort into fixing the core game's issues, such as balancing and bugs.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/ubisoft-delays-the-next-two-division-expansions-to-focus-on-fixing-the-game/?|title=Ubisoft delays the next two Division expansions to Ubisoft delays the next two Division expansions to focus on fixing the game|first=Andy|last=Chalk|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=August 26, 2016|accessdate=August 26, 2016}} ''Survival'' was available on all platforms by December.{{cite web|url=https://www.gamezone.com/news/the-division-s-survival-dlc-has-launched-on-playstation-4-3446704/|title=The Division’s Survival DLC has launched on PlayStation 4|first=Atle|last=Williatham|work=GameZone|date=December 22, 2016|accessdate=February 2, 2018}} ''Last Stand'' was released on 28 February 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.bleedingcool.com/2017/02/28/division-got-8-5gb-update-today-along-dlc-free-trial/|title=The Division Got An 8.5GB Update Today Along With DLC And A Free Trial|first=Madelinr|last=Ricchuito|work=[[Bleeding Cool]]|date=February 28, 2017|accessdate=6 February 2018}} Ubisoft in March 2017 revealed plans for a second year of additional content with two free expansions.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2017-03-09-theres-good-news-and-bad-news-on-the-division-year-two|title=There's good news and bad news on The Division year two|first=Wesley|last=Yin-Poole|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=March 8, 2017|accessdate=1 March 2018}} Update 1.7 was released on 15 August including additional features and tweaks. The update added "Global Events", limited-time events with gameplay modifiers that give special rewards. In addition, it also adds the ability to customize a character's face, cosmetic items as well as "Commendations" which replaces "Feats".{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-divisions-17-update-out-now-here-are-the-patch/1100-6452530/|title=The Division's 1.7 Update Out Now, Here Are The Patch Notes|first=Chris|last=Pereira|work=[[Gamespot]]|date=15 August 2017|accessdate=1 March 2018}} Update 1.8 was released on 5 December 2017. It adds a new area called West Side Pier as well as two new games modes called Resistance and Skirmish. In Resistance, the player has to fend off waves of enemies. Skirmish is a multiplayer mode where teams of four players have to achieve the highest kill-count.{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/glixel/news/the-division-update-18-adds-new-gameplay-modes-and-area-w513364|title='The Division' Update 1.8 Adds New Gameplay Modes and Area|first=Blake|last=Hester|work=Rolling Stone|date=5 December 2017|accessdate=1 March 2018}} ==Reception== === Reviews === {{Video game reviews | MC = (PS4) 80/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-4/tom-clancys-the-division |title=Tom Clancy's The Division for PlayStation 4 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=9 March 2016}}
(XONE) 80/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-one/tom-clancys-the-division |title=Tom Clancy's The Division for Xbox One Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=9 March 2016}}
(PC) 79/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/tom-clancys-the-division |title=Tom Clancy's The Division for PC Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=9 March 2016}} | Destruct = 6.5/10{{cite web |last=Carter |first=Chris |date=14 March 2016 |url=http://www.destructoid.com/review-tom-clancy-s-the-division-348421.phtml |title=Review: Tom Clancy's The Division PlayStation 4 |publisher=[[Game Informer]] |accessdate=15 March 2016}} | GSpot = 8/10{{cite web |last=Butterworth |first=Scott |date=13 March 2016 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/tom-clancys-the-division-review/1900-6416380/ |title=Tom Clancy's The Division Review |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | GameRev = {{Rating|3.5|5}}{{cite web |last=Paras |first=Peter |date=21 March 2016 |url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/tom-clancys-the-division |title=Tom Clancy's The Division Review |publisher=[[Game Revolution]] |accessdate=21 March 2016}} | GRadar = {{Rating|4|5}}{{cite web |last=Hartup |first=Andy |date=23 March 2016 |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/tom-clancys-division-review/ |title=Tom
