|url=http://www.giantbomb.com/reviews/tom-clancys-the-division-review/1900-738/ |title=Tom Clancy's The Division Review |publisher=[[Giant Bomb]] |accessdate=14 March 2016}} | IGN = 6.7/10{{cite web |last=Ingenito |first=Vince |date=16 March 2016 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/03/17/the-division-review |title=Tom Clancy's The Division Review |work=[[IGN]] |accessdate=16 March 2016}} | PCGUS = 68/100{{cite web |last=Davenport |first=James |date=15 March 2016 |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/tom-clancys-the-division-review/ |title=Tom Clancy's The Division review |publisher=[[PC Gamer]] |accessdate=15 March 2016}} | Poly = 7/10{{cite web |last=Gies |first=Arthur |date=15 March 2016 |url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/3/15/11224502/the-division-review-ps4-xbox-one-pc |title=The Division review |publisher=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |accessdate=15 March 2016}} | VG = 8/10{{cite web |last=Bell |first=Alice |date=10 March 2016 |url=http://www.videogamer.com/reviews/tom_clancys_the_division_review.html |title=Tom Clancy's The Division Review |publisher=VideoGamer.com |accessdate=10 March 2016}} }} ''Tom Clancy's The Division'' received "generally favourable" reviews according to review aggregator, [[Metacritic]]. ''[[Ars Technica]]'' drew comparisons between ''The Division'' and ''[[Destiny (video game)|Destiny]]'', a first-person shooter game with similar overall mechanics regarding items, crafting, and "shared world" elements. The game was also compared to "modern" [[massively multiplayer online role-playing game]]s (MMORPG), explaining that "structurally, it all feels like it could have been ripped from ''[[Guild Wars 2]]'' or a latter-day ''[[World of Warcraft]],''" including "that old MMO staple of being stuck in a server queue before diving into a game" on-launch, in combination with the "quintessential Ubisoft design style" of varying types of collectible and upgrade systems. ''The Division'' was criticized for lacking variety in its activities and missions, explaining that it "does little to break from or advance what is fast becoming the general form of the "loot shooter" genre. In fact, it takes very few risks at all, particularly with its enemies and encounter design." The Dark Zone was described as being "harrowing", but was panned for sharing characteristics with the post-game content of ''Destiny'', as being the only means of obtaining higher-level gear that is, ultimately, only theoretically needed for further play in the Dark Zone, and for not introducing any major differences in gameplay mechanics like the raids of ''Destiny''.{{cite web|title=The Division review: Mistakes were made, both old and new|url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2016/03/the-division-review-mistakes-were-made-both-old-and-new/|website=Ars Technica|publisher=Conde Nast|accessdate=13 March 2016}} Vince Ingenito of ''IGN'' was more critical of ''The Division'', outlining that "next to every good thing ''The Division'' does, there hangs a big, ugly asterisk". The overall atmosphere was panned for being "barren and unengaging" overall; as examples, Ingenito focused upon the lack of dynamic events in the game world, that there were "long stretches of eventless walking where very little happens" due to the lack of events and encounters, the lack of variety in missions and activities, and that the grid layout of Manhattan made navigation and exploration "tedious". The gun mechanics of ''The Division'' were described as being "standard" and more in line with the more realistic feel of other ''Tom Clancy''-branded games, with guns that had distinct feels due to their varying statistics, and that "the fact that the action leans so heavily on smart tactics makes it rewarding when the last foe in a pack finally goes down." The progression system was also criticized for being "fractured", requiring that players visit multiple locations with different systems in order to upgrade their abilities, explaining that "[it's] hard to accurately gauge just how strong you really are, and as a result, easy to get in over your head in a mission that your character level indicates you can handle." While noting that its "post-game" content was mainly limited to harder versions of story missions with stronger "bullet sponge" enemies, Ingenito praised the Dark Zone for "[fixing] just about every problem I have with ''The Division's'' pacing, its lack of player-driven moments, and the overall toothlessness and emptiness of its open world", by adding an "omnipresent" danger and a higher degree of risk to player interactions. In conclusion, Ingenito felt that the game's ideas and mechanics were "not spread evenly or interwoven cleanly enough to form a cohesive, consistently enjoyable loop". {{anchor|Notable glitch}}Prior to version 1.0.2 of the game, named enemy [[non-player character|NPCs]] would respawn indefinitely, as long as their entourage of minions were never killed. This allowed players to collect the named enemies' superior and high-end loot over and over again. The most popular target of this [[exploit (video game)|exploit]] was a character known as the Bullet King, as this character was the named enemy closest to any player spawn point in the game.[http://www.kotaku.com.au/2016/03/heres-a-good-way-to-farm-items-and-phoenix-credits-inthe-division/ Here's a Good Way to Farm Items and Phoenix Credits in ''The Division'']. ''[[Kotaku]]'', March 2016[https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2016/03/21/bullet-king-is-the-divisions-loot-cave/ Bullet King is ''The Division's'' loot cave]. ''[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]'', 21 March 2016[http://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-division-dev-addressing-loot-cave-with-new-upd/1100-6435853/ The Division dev addressing loot cave with new update]. ''[[GameSpot]]''[http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-03-21-the-division-phoenix-credits-farming-spot-found ''The Division'' Phoenix credits farming spot found]. ''[[Eurogamer]]''. 21 March 2016 The glitch has been resolved in patch 1.0.2 of the game,{{cite web|url=http://tomclancy-thedivision.ubi.com/game/en-gb/news/detail.aspx?c=tcm:154-242994-16&ct=tcm:148-76770-32|title=Tom Clancy's The Division version 1.0.2 release notes}} released by Ubisoft on March 22, 2016. ===Sales=== According to Ubisoft, the game broke company records, including highest number of first-day sales{{cite web|last1=Varanini|first1=Giancarlo|title=The Division Breaks Ubisoft Records|url=http://blog.ubi.com/the-division-sets-new-sales-records/|website=Ubiblog|accessdate=April 30, 2016|date=March 9, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160318050333/http://blog.ubi.com/the-division-sets-new-sales-records/|archivedate=18 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} (breaking the record previously set by ''[[Watch Dogs]]'' in 2014), and becoming the company's best-selling game. ''The Division'' also broke the industry record for biggest first-week launch for a new game franchise, generating an estimated amount of $330 million globally.{{cite web|last1=Varanini|first1=Giancarlo|title=The Division Has Biggest First Week Ever for New Game Franchise|url=http://blog.ubi.com/the-division-has-biggest-first-week-ever-for-new-game-franchise/|website=Ubiblog|accessdate=April 30, 2016|date=March 15, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317203840/http://blog.ubi.com/the-division-has-biggest-first-week-ever-for-new-game-franchise/|archivedate=17 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} The retail version of ''The Division'' was the best selling game in its week of release in the U.K. and Ireland, debuting at No. 1 in the UK retail software sales chart. The game's launch marked the biggest video game debut in the [[calendar year|first quarter of the year]] in the U.K., breaking the record previously held by Sony's ''[[Gran Turismo 4]]''. It was the third biggest launch of a Ubisoft game in the U.K., behind ''[[Assassin's Creed III]]'' and ''Watch Dogs''.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-03-14-the-division-is-uks-biggest-ever-q1-launch|title=The Division is UK's biggest ever Q1 launch|first=Tom|last=Phillips|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=March 14, 2015|accessdate=March 14, 2016}} The game has the highest week one sales for a new [[intellectual property]], breaking the record held by ''[[Destiny (video game)|Destiny]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-03-15-the-division-sets-world-record-for-best-selling-new-ip|title=The Division claims fastest-selling new games IP crown|first=Jeffery|last=Matulef|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=15 March 2016|accessdate=16 March 2016}} The game was No. 1 in Japan, selling over 80,000 units in its first week.{{cite web|url=http://www.mcvuk.com/news/read/the-division-outsells-zelda-twilight-princess-in-japan/0164127|title=The Division outsells Zelda Twilight Princess in Japan|first=Ben|last=Parffit|work=[[Market for Home Computing and Video Games]]|date=March 16, 2016|accessdate=March 17, 2016}} [[The NPD Group]] indicated that the retail version of ''The Division'' was the best selling game in March 2016 in the U.S.{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/04/14/march-2016-npd-division-zelda/|title=March 2016 NPD: Ubisoft, Nintendo shake up sales chart with The Division, Zelda|first=Jeff|last=Grubb|date=14 April 2016|website=[[VentureBeat]]}} ==Film adaptation== In June 2016, it was announced that a live action feature film adaption of ''The Division'' is in development, with [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] in the starring role. Gyllenhaal will co-produce the film with CEO of Ubisoft, Gerard Guillemot.{{cite news|last=Kroll|first=Justin|title=Jake Gyllenhaal to Star in Ubisoft’s ‘The Division’ Movie (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/jake-gyllenhaal-the-division-movie-1201742202/|accessdate=June 2, 2016|work=Variety|date=June 1, 2016}} By August of the same year, [[Jessica Chastain]] was cast in the co-starring role of the film.{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/jessica-chastain-jake-gyllenhaal-the-division-tom-clancy-video-game-adaptation-ubisoft/|title=Jessica Chastain Joins Jake Gyllenhaal in Tom Clancy Video Game Adaptation ‘The Division’|publisher=The Wrap|last=Nakamura|first=Reid|date=August 2, 2016}} By January 2017, [[Stephen Gaghan]] was attached to direct,{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/stephen-gaghan-division-movie-jake-gyllenhaal-and-jessica-chastain-1201962733/|title=Stephen Gaghan to Direct ‘The Division’ Movie Starring Jake Gyllenhaal and Jessica Chastain (EXCLUSIVE)|publisher=Variety|last=Kroll|first=Justin|date=January 19, 2017}} though he left the project in 2018. In April 2018, [[David Leitch (director)|David Leitch]] signed on to direct/co-produce the film. Kelly McCormick, Gyllenhaal, Riva Marker, Chastain and Kelly Carmichael will co-produce.{{cite web|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=‘Deadpool 2’s’ David Leitch to Direct Jessica Chastain, Jake Gyllenhaal in ‘The Division’ (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/david-leitch-the-division-jessica-chastain-jake-gyllenhaal-deadpool-2-1202764110/|publisher=''Variety''|accessdate=19 April 2018}} == Sequel == On 9 March 2018, a sequel to the game, ''[[Tom Clancy's The Division 2]]'', was announced, that was currently being worked on by [[Massive Entertainment]].{{cite web |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-03-08-the-division-2-details-leak-online-ahead-of-announcement |title=The Division 2 details leak online ahead of announcement |last=Philips |first=Tom |date=8 March 2018 |access-date=14 June 2018 |work=[[Eurogamer]] |publisher=[[Gamer Network]]}}{{cite web |url=https://www.vg247.com/2018/03/08/division-2-currently-works-massive-entertainment/ |title=The Division 2 is currently in the works at Massive Entertainment, more to come at E3 2018 |last=Nunneley |first=Stephen |date=8 March 2018 |access-date=18 March 2018 |work=[[vg247]]}} The game was officially premiered at the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2018]] in June 2018.{{Cite journal |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/the-division-2-will-release-within-a-year-ubisoft-confirms/ |title=The Division 2 will release within the next 12 months, Ubisoft confirms |access-date=20 May 2018 |date=May 2018 |last=Horti |first=Samuel |publisher=Future, Inc. |magazine=[[PCGamer]]}} On June 10, 2018, ''Tom Clancy’s The Division 2'' was announced to be released on 15 March 2019, with the game set to take place within Washington D.C. after it falls into anarchy, and six months after the events of ''Tom Clancy's The Division''.{{cite web |url=https://www.polygon.com/e3/2018/6/10/17429932/tom-clancys-the-division-2-release-date-preview-video-e3-2018 |title=Tom Clancy’s The Division 2 launches next March |last=Goslin |first=Austen |last2=Good |first2=Owen S. |date=10 June 2018 |access-date=14 June 2018 |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |publisher=[[Vox Media, Inc.]]}} ==Notes== {{For|animal behaviors and structures|Trap-lining|Trap line (spiders)}} {{globalize/Canada|date=April 2014}} [[File:WoodcockTrapLine.jpg|thumb|A photo of a trapper on his line from the 1913 American autobiography ''[[Fifty Years a Hunter and Trapper]]'']] [[File:Brooks Range (29) Trapper's cabin.jpg|thumb|A photo of a modern trapper's cabin from the [[Brooks Range]] in [[Alaska]]]] In the [[fur trade]], a '''trapline''' is a route along which a [[trapping|trapper]] sets traps for his or her quarry. Trappers traditionally move habitually along the route to set and check the traps, in so doing become skilled at traversing remote terrain, and become experts in the geography of the local area. Because of this [[traditional knowledge]], traplines are not only of interest to trappers themselves but to researchers and others (governments, corporations) interested in local history, biology, and topography. The assignment of particular trapline territories to individuals in [[band societies]] was traditionally handled by group consensus, and occasionally violence and warfare. In the present-day trapline assignment is typically formalized and controlled by the state. Formalized trapline territory boundaries now form the basis for many major land-use projects in fur-rich regions.
One of the entitlements that goes along with possessing a trap territory is the right to erect a '''trapper’s cabin''': a simple shelter in which a trapper can stay while moving around his territory. Trappers' cabins are a [[cultural icon]] of fur regions, and an important part of the [[national mythos]] of countries and regions such as [[Canada]] and [[Alaska]], and among groups such as the [[Métis people|Métis]].
== Pre-treaty indigenous governance of trapping and other harvesting == {{see|Keyoh}} Before European colonisation, determining where a particular family or band could hunt, fish, and gather without encroaching on others to the point of over-harvesting was the main preoccupation of indigenous governance in the [[subartic peoples|subarctic]] and other non-farming regions. Councils were convened to reconcile disputes and warfare was always a possibility.
When European traders began exporting bulk amounts of fur to Europe in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, the trapping territories of the subarctic became much more commercially valuable and disputes intensified.
== Registered traplines == In Canada formal trapping territories assigned by the state are typically called "'''registered traplines'''" (RTLs), though each province administers its own system; they have been common across Canada since the 1930s.
Alberta's registered traplines were once exactly that: lines which followed a [[Stream|creek]] or other feature, but in the 1960s they were switched to a system of trapping territories.<ref name="Notzke">Notzke, 125.</ref>
In British Columbia "the registered trapline system continues to be the primary system for setting harvest guidelines and managing furbearing animals". It is an offence to trap an animal on a registered trapline that does not belong to you in BC.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.env.gov.bc.ca/fw/wildlife/hunting/regulations/1214/docs/trapping_Section.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114140542/http://www.env.gov.bc.ca/fw/wildlife/hunting/regulations/1214/docs/trapping_Section.pdf |archivedate=2014-01-14 |df= }}</ref>
Manitoba has had registered traplines since 1940; they were brought in at that time to stop a wave of new arrivals in [[Northern Manitoba]] from trapping out an area that was already overharvested by the local, mostly [[First Nations in Manitoba|First Nations]], population. The system is administered under the province's ''[[Mantioba Wildlife Act|Wildlife Act]]''. Lines cannot be sold, inherited, or handed down, but are awarded through a points system, where preference is given to people with a close family relationship to the previous lineholder, a history of using that trapline with the permission of the previous lienholder, and residency near the territory.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.mb.ca/conservation/wildlife/trapping/rtl_lines.html |title=Manitoba Trapping Guide | Wildlife & Ecosystem Protection — Conservation | Province of Manitoba |publisher=Gov.mb.ca |date= |accessdate=2014-01-16}}</ref>
{{As of|2013}} Ontario has more than 2,800 registered traplines on [[Crown land]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mnr.gov.on.ca/en/Business/FW/2ColumnSubPage/STEL02_168422.html |title=Trapping in Ontario - Ontario Government, Ministry of Natural Resources |publisher=Mnr.gov.on.ca |date= |accessdate=2014-01-16}}</ref>
Since the 2001 ''[[Paix des braves]]'' agreement, trapline territories have been used as the basis for forestry and mining planning in the [[Eeyou Istchee (territory)|Eeyou Istchee territory]], in [[Quebec]].<ref name="TindallTrosper2013">{{cite book|author1=D.B. Tindall|author2=Ronald Trosper|author3=Pamela Perreault|title=Aboriginal Peoples and Forest Lands in Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gdfzyzKjJg0C&pg=PA143|date=11 February 2013|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=978-0-7748-2336-4|page=143}}</ref>
=== Indigenous land claims === Indigenous peoples have not always welcomed the regulation of the fur industry by provincial authorities, and the assignment of trapping territories by the provincial Crown implies that the land is ultimately the property of the province, to be disposed of at its will, rather than subject to [[Comanagement in Canada|comanagement]] under the terms of the treaties. Furthermore, having to apply to provincial authorities to distribute traplines removes control of the process from local Indigenous forms of governance, and institutionalizes a non-Indigenous presence on traditional lands.<ref name="Notzke" /> Nevertheless, as registered traplines provide Aboriginal peoples with legal rights to a piece of land off-reserve, a potential economic livelihood, and a connection to a traditional lifestyle, registered traplines are considered of the utmost importance for many First Nations and Metis communities.<ref>Notzke, 126.</ref>
